Otter View Park.name: Otter View Park
Otter View Park.trailhead: Parking is located at the corner of Weybridge Rd and Pulp Mill Bridge Rd.
Otter View Park.features: Boardwalk to a scenic viewpoint on Otter Creek

Plouffe Lane Trail.name: Plouffe Lane Trail
Plouffe Lane Trail.trailhead: From Route 7 South  and Church Hill road take Church Hill Road to  the stop sign and turn right onto Hinesburg Road. Take Hinesburg Road to Spear Street and turn left.  Take Spear Street approximately 1.3 miles and take a right onto Carpenter Road. Plouffe Lane will be a short distance down the road on your left. Follow the road to the end (there is a red gate), open the gate and park your car inside.
Plouffe Lane Trail.features: 80 acres of meadows and woodlands.  Views of the Green Mountains.

Kilowatt North and South Parks.name: Kilowatt North and South  Parks
Kilowatt North and South Parks.trailhead: From Wilder Village RT5 near village store - to Depot Street - over RR bridge - Kilowatt South straight ahead,  Follow signs to Kilowatt South / Wilder Picnic Area
Kilowatt North and South Parks.features: Trail connects the two park properties: Kilowatt North & Kilowatt South.  Trail follws along the Connecticut River

Lyme Town Forest.name: Lyme Town Forest
Lyme Town Forest.trailhead: From Lyme Common, travel 1.6 miles north on Route 10. Turn right onto Pinnacle Road. In 1.6 miles turn left onto Orfordville Road. Look for the large blue sign marking the Town Forest parking area, on the left in 0.8 miles. The trail starts here.
Lyme Town Forest.features:
The 382-acre tract includes a 1985 acquisition from the Sevigney Company, and an addition purchased in 2002 with proceeds from timber sales. Terrain varies from wetlands to ledge outcrops, with elevations ranging from 780 to 1220 feet. Whipple Brook and Mud Turtle Pond Road, a Class VI road linking Whipple Hill Road with Orford's Strawberry Hill, bisect the Forest. The Lyme Town Forest is a certified NH Tree
Farm.

Camel's Hump Nordic Ski Area.name: Camel's Hump Nordic Ski Area
Camel's Hump Nordic Ski Area.trailhead: From I-89, take exit 11 to Rte. 2 east to the village of Richmond. There, turn right onto Main Road and drive about 7-8 miles to Huntington. In Huntington, bear left at a Y intersection onto East Street (about 2.5 miles to ski center parking from here).  Continue on East Street, until it bears right and go straight onto Bert White Road. Turn left onto Handy Road and go about .5 miles up the hill to parking lot on the left just before the road bends sharply right.  The trailhead is directly across the road.
Camel's Hump Nordic Ski Area.features:
Winter Use Only. Maintained by the Camels Hump Nordic Ski Area (CHNSA) www.camelshumpskiers.org . Many miles of beautiful wooded cross country ski trails ranging in skill level.  Connects to Catamount Trail - Dark Blue segments on map.  No dogs allowed.
Note: Northwestern sections of the trails system are closed for logging during the 2012/2013 winter season.  Consult the web site  www.camelshumpskiers.org/trailmaps.html for details

Otter Creek Gorge Preserve.name: Otter Creek Gorge Preserve
Otter Creek Gorge Preserve.trailhead: Parking area on Horse Farm Road, 0.2 mile north of the junction with Hamilton Rd.
Otter Creek Gorge Preserve.features: Otter Creek Gorge Preserve Trail is part of the Trail Around Middlebury (TAM), a 17-mile loop around the Town of Middlebury. This section is along the Otter Creek.

Old Red Mill Park.name: Old Red Mill Park
Old Red Mill Park.trailhead: Going East on Route 15 into Jericho, turn left just after the Citgo gas station, immediately before the river. Continue a few yards past the Old Red Mill to the parking area.
Old Red Mill Park.features: Historic riverscape with waterfall and pools

Forestdale Natural Area.name: Forestdale Natural Area
Forestdale Natural Area.trailhead:
Access: 1) behind the residential utilities off Laurel Drive, 2) along Allen Martin
Parkway, and 3) across from Hillside Circle on Saxon Hollow Road. Limited on-street parking is available at all three access points.
Forestdale Natural Area.features: A short loop, easily accessible from Essex town.

Knight Point State Park.name: Knight Point State Park
Knight Point State Park.trailhead:
This state park is to the west of Rt 2 in North Hero. From the south on US Route 2, the entrance is the first left after the North Hero/Grand Isle drawbridge. (From the north on US Route 2, the entrance is the last right before the North Hero/Grand Isle drawbridge).
The park (and trail) are open year 'round. Between Memorial Day Weekend and Labor Day a fee is charged and the restrooms are open.
Knight Point State Park.features: An easy, flat, short hike. Many access points from the center of the park. Beach Facilities at the park. Many viewpoints along the trail overlook the lake, and there are several large old-growth maple and oak trees.

Skylight Pond.name: Skylight Pond
Skylight Pond.features: The path of Skylight Pond still ranks among the most popular trails in the state. A choice of summits, an alpine pond, and one of the Long Trail's (LT) newest lodges transform this temperate trail into a champion of mid-range hikes.

The Spirit in Nature Path.name: The Spirit in Nature Path
The Spirit in Nature Path.trailhead: Travel south on Route 5 from Norwich past the Subaru dealership and King Arthur Flour. The church is on the right hand side of the road across from Fogg’s Hardware Store.
The Spirit in Nature Path.features:
Walk on paths that wind through the woods behind the Unitarian Universalist Church on Route 5.
Inspirational quotes and natural science (plants) information are offered along the trail.
Experience the inspiration that nature can give.

Pine Point Trail.name: Pine Point Trail
Pine Point Trail.trailhead:
Travel south on Main Street Hanover heading downslope to cross Mink Brook. Turn right (east) into the Pine Knoll Cemetery.
Stay left at Y in driveway and continue until reaching The Wastewater Treatment Facility gate at the back of the property. Use parking area just to the right of the gate.
Walk east to reach paved driveway on your left.  Turn left to reach northwest corner of cemetery where Pine Point trailhead is located.
Pine Point Trail.features: Short trail from the Pine Knoll Cemetery to Mink Brook.

Ti-Haul Trail.name: Ti-Haul Trail
Ti-Haul Trail.trailhead: From Shelburne Road (Route 7), turn west onto Bay Road. Go under the railroad tracks and look for parking on your right, just past the boat access. The trailhead is on the other side of Bay Road. The southern trailhead is on Harbor Road about 0.6 mile from the village center, but has no parking available.
Ti-Haul Trail.features: A unique maritime preservation road that is now open to recreational uses.

Vermont Wildflower Farm.name: Vermont Wildflower Farm
Vermont Wildflower Farm.trailhead:
From Rte 7 South: After passing through the village of  Middlebury, the  Wildflower Farm is approximately 20 miles ahead on your left, as you enter the Town of Charlotte, VT.
From either the north or South, via Interstate 89: From I-89, take exit 13 onto I-189. Go left onto Route 7 South towards Shelburne. The Wildflower farm is approximately 10 miles from the Interstate Exit, just 5 miles south of Shelburne Village.
From the West, through New York State - two ways:


Enter Vermont on US Rt 4 at FairHaven, VT and travel north on Rt 7; follow directions above "from Route 7 south."


Take the Essex, NY ferry across Lake Champlain. The ferry is a scenic 15 minute ride; the dock is just 10 minutes from the Wildflower Farm. Simply exit the boat, follow the signs to Route 7, and turn right. It's about 500 ft. ahead on your right.
Vermont Wildflower Farm.features: 1/4 mile walking trail through extensive wildflower gardens, located right on Rte 7. Seed shop, gift shop, travel information.

Boltonville Nature Trail.name: Boltonville Nature Trail
Boltonville Nature Trail.trailhead: Trailhead parking at the Boltonville Trailhead for the Cross Vermont Trail, on Rte 302 just east of the jct of 302 and Boltonville Rd.
Boltonville Nature Trail.features: Foot path through Wells River natural area.

Ethan Allen Park.name: Ethan Allen Park
Ethan Allen Park.trailhead: From Burlington, take North Avenue to the New North End. Continue past the Route 127 off-ramp. The park entrance is on the right at the corner of North Avenue and Ethan Allen Parkway.
Ethan Allen Park.features: Wooded urban refuge offers historic lookout over Burlington and Lake Champlain region.

Lake Champlain Bikeway.name: Lake Champlain Bikeway
Lake Champlain Bikeway.features:
The map at present just shows the VT and NY main North-South routes. Many additional loops are suggested on the Lake Champlain Bikeways map - see ChamplainBikeways.org.
The Bikeways steer day riders and  bicycle touring riders along peaceful country roads, through picturesque villages, breathtaking scenery, charming B&B's and inns, country stores and farmstands, impressive historic sites and museums, lovely shoreline parks and campgrounds.  Resources include  bicycle tour outfitters, convenient connections to passenger rail lines and ferry crossings, and access to numerous lakes and rivers.

Hartford Town Forest.name: Hartford Town Forest
Hartford Town Forest.trailhead: Access to the Hartford Town Forest is from Route 4 to Center of Town Road. There are two ways to access Center of Town Road, one from the Quechee (west side) of Exit 1 of I-89 and the other from the White River Junction (east side) of Exit 1. Once on Center of Town Road, turn onto Kings Highway across from the Meeting House Common. Follow 0.7 miles and turn right onto Reservoir Road. Follow approximately 0.8 miles to the Trailhead Parking Area.
Hartford Town Forest.features: The Hartford Town Forest is a 423-acre parcel that has approximately 4 miles of mixed-use trails.

Long Trail.name: Long Trail
Long Trail.trailhead: The Long Trail is accessible from numerous points throughout Vermont. Please consult the Green Mountain Club for detailed directions.
Long Trail.features: With its 270-mile footpath, 175 miles of side trails, and nearly 70 primitive shelters, the Long Trail offers endless hiking opportunities for the day hiker, weekend overnighter, and extended backpacker.

Riverside Trail.name: Riverside Trail
Riverside Trail.trailhead: From Exit 20 on I-89, travel north on Route 12A for 0.5 miles. Turn right onto Glen Road and continue to the second driveway into the Powerhouse Mall. Park near the gazebo on far end of the parking lot behind EMS. Alternatively continue on Glen Road to the entrance-way for Riverside Community Park on your right.
Riverside Trail.features:
This gently sloped firm surface trail provides great accessibility between the Powerhouse Mall and Lebanon's Riverside Community Park.
The 5-6' wide trail surface allows for side by side walking and easy passing for oncoming trail users.
You'll be able to take in some nice views of the Mascoma River, and access nearby shopping and some fun recreational features.

Wilder Multi-Use Path.name: Wilder Multi-Use Path
Wilder Multi-Use Path.trailhead: The north end of the Wilder Multi-use Path is located at the Dothan Brook School on Route 5, 0.5 miles south of the Hartford/Norwich town line.  Parking is available in the School parking lot.  The south end of the Multi-use Path is located at the corner of Colonial Drive and Route 5 in Wilder Village, 0.2 miles north of the Wilder Church. Although parking is available on many Wilder Village streets, parking is not available at the south entrance to the Multi-use Path.
Wilder Multi-Use Path.features:
The Wilder Multi-Use Path is a paved path that was built to provide students with a safe place to walk between Wilder Village and the Dothan Brook School.
The path also receives regular recreational and transportation use by pedestrians and bicyclists.

Woodside Natural Area and Overlook Park.name: Woodside Natural Area and Overlook Park
Woodside Natural Area and Overlook Park.trailhead: Take Route 15 east past St. Michael's College. Opposite the West Dalton Drive entrance to Fort Ethan Allen, turn off Route 15 onto Woodside Drive. Overlook Park is just off Woodside Drive on the left. The trailhead and parking for Woodside Natural Area is 0.25 mile down Woodside Drive on the right.
Woodside Natural Area and Overlook Park.features: Quick access to the Winooski River and wildlife natural area.

U32 Woods Trails.name: U32 Woods Trails
U32 Woods Trails.trailhead:
The U-32 Woods Trail can be accessed at several locations:
The closest parking can be found behind the WCSU building located in the most northern part of the property. The trailhead is located in front of the building near the old tree with a metal ring around it.
The trail can also be accessed by parking behind WCSU and walking east to the left of the tennis courts.
Users can also park in the Middle School Lot located slightly behind the school in the most southern part of the property. Follow the dirt road behind the school towards the trailhead which is located behind the baseball backstop.
U32 Woods Trails.features: Convenient parking, quiet, terrain for mixed abilities, a quarter-mile self directed nature trail designed by U-32 Science students.

Kluge Trails.name: Kluge Trails
Kluge Trails.trailhead: From Route 4 at 4A, follow 4A for 3.6 miles continuing past Mascoma Lake to reach Shaker Recreation Park on left, continue on 4A for 2 more miles and turn left onto Shaker Hill Road., in 0.4 miles pass by Crystal Lake Road and continue for an additional 0.7 mile to Kluge Road. Turn right, proceed for 0.4 mile, passing by Sunrise Farm on right. Limited parking at edge of road on right next to Dustin Road (a Class VI road). During dry conditions travel up Dustin Road to park at clearing (log landing).
Kluge Trails.features: A network of recreational trails and wood roads located on private lands open to public use. Connecting Dustin, Lockehaven and Kluge Road with Crystal Lake Road.

Robert Frost Interpretive Trail.name: Robert Frost Interpretive Trail
Robert Frost Interpretive Trail.trailhead: The trail head is in the Town of Ripton on Route 125.
Robert Frost Interpretive Trail.features: Interpretive trail filled with Robert Frost's poetry, contemplative woods, and a beaver pond. Total time: 30-45 minutes.

Sand Hill Park.name: Sand Hill Park
Sand Hill Park.trailhead: Take Route 15 east to Sand Hill Road. After 0.1 mile, turn right at the park entrance. Parking is available in the town pool lot.
Sand Hill Park.features: Shady forested trail near Essex town pool and tennis courts.

Austin Brook Trail.name: Austin Brook Trail
Austin Brook Trail.features: The trail follows unplowed Forest Road 25 as it climbs steadily along Austin Brook through a mixed hardwood/softwood forest.

Essex Overlook Park.name: Essex Overlook Park
Essex Overlook Park.trailhead: Take Route 15 east past St. Michael's College. Turn right onto Woodside Drive and take an immediate left into the parking area.
Essex Overlook Park.features: Picnic area with scenic views of Vermont's mountains. No trails.

Deer Leap.name: Deer Leap
Deer Leap.trailhead: Take Route 4 East from Rutland or West from Killington to the top of Sherburne Pass. A few parking spots on the north side / trailhead side of Route 4 and many places on the south side. Be extremely careful crossing Route 4.
Deer Leap.features: Rock Cliff Summit Vista with excellent views to the south including Killington, Pico, and Blue Ridge.

Cooley Glen/Emily Proctor Trails.name: Cooley Glen/Emily Proctor Trails
Cooley Glen/Emily Proctor Trails.trailhead: The trail head is in the Town of Lincoln on Forest Road 201.
Cooley Glen/Emily Proctor Trails.features: Stream views, Long Trail access. Combine three trails for a nice overnight backpacking trip. Total loop is 13 miles.

Stonehedge Woods.name: Stonehedge Woods
Stonehedge Woods.trailhead: The Woods are tucked in between Swift Street, Stonehedge Drive and Brewer Parkway. Visitors may access the woods via the South Burlington Rec Path. Parking is available off Swift St in Farrell Park, then take the paved rec path East to find the trailhead.
Stonehedge Woods.features: Beautiful hemlock and pine stands with trail leading to quiet ponds.

Moosalamoo Trail.name: Moosalamoo Trail
Moosalamoo Trail.trailhead: Trail head is in the Town of Goshen on Forest Road 24.
Moosalamoo Trail.features: A relatively short hike to the summit of Mount Moosalamoo.

Arms Park.name: Arms Park
Arms Park.trailhead: Access the trail from the Burlington Bike Path just south of Leddy Park (parking available at Leddy Park). Trailhead also at Burlington High School: there is an uphill path paved with marble chips that starts between the high school parking lot and the bus turnabout. Trailhead and parking also at the Episcopal Diocese Offices on Rock Point Road. Trail starting at this trailhead is open to foot traffic only.
Arms Park.features: Informal trails behind Burlington High School

Webster Road Path.name: Webster Road Path
Webster Road Path.features: paved multi use trail on Webster Rd in Shelburne

Kingsbury Bridge Greenway.name: Kingsbury Bridge Greenway
Kingsbury Bridge Greenway.trailhead: The trail starts from Warren’s Riverside Park on Route 100.
Kingsbury Bridge Greenway.features: 1.4 Mile loop around Sugarbush snowmaking pond.

Lake Morey Ice Skating Trail.name: Lake Morey Ice Skating Trail
Lake Morey Ice Skating Trail.trailhead: From I-91 take exit 15 in Fairlee. Off the ramp: turn west and take Lake Morey Rd West. Follow signs to the Lake Morey Resort. Park on west side of resort and walk around building to Ice Trail entrance.
Lake Morey Ice Skating Trail.features: Groomed Ice Skating Trail. Longest groomed skating trail in the United States.

Button Bay State Park.name: Button Bay State Park
Button Bay State Park.trailhead: Enter Button Bay State Park, drive and park at the west end, past the camping areas, near the Pavilion. Follow signs for trail.
Button Bay State Park.features: Great Lake Champlain shore line and views. Very nice small Nature Center near Button Point. Camping, picnicking, swimming, pool are all available.

French's Ledges Trails.name: French's Ledges Trails
French's Ledges Trails.trailhead:
From Route 120 in Meriden, NH, turn west at the yellow flashing light onto Main Street and go 0.8 miles, over the hill past Kimball Union Academy (KUA) and down to a covered bridge. Turn left onto Colby Hill Road, going through the covered bridge.

North Trailhead: From the covered bridge go 0.4 mile on Colby Hill Road to a small pull-off on your left for the start of the French’s Ledges Trail.
Middle Trailhead: From the covered bridge go 0.9 mile on Colby Hill Road and turn left onto Columbus Jordan Road. Parking will be on your right along Columbus Jordan Road, half a mile from its junction with Colby Hill Road. The blue-blazed Farnum Loop Trail enters the woods about 25 yards from the parking area across a mowed field to the west. On the other side of the road, to the east, is a yellow-blazed connector trail that links with the French’s Ledges Trail, bringing you to the Ledges in just over three-quarters of a mile. Continue on Columbus
Jordan Rd. to the South Trailhead where a blue-blazed trail will lead you to the Ledges.
During non-school hours, parking may be available for access to the eastern portion of these trails at Plainfield Elementary School off Baynes Road.
French's Ledges Trails.features: Provides a wide variety of trails to suit many abilities.

A Legacy of Ancient Stone.name: A Legacy of Ancient Stone
A Legacy of Ancient Stone.trailhead: St. Anne's Shrine Pavilion. Follow Route 129 and cross the causeway to Isle LaMotte. Bear right on Shrine Road until you arrive at St. Anne's Pavilion.
A Legacy of Ancient Stone.features: Isle LaMotte is rich with geologic history with limestone quarries, an old Catholic shrine, and quiet dirt and paved roads.

Shillingford Crossing.name: Shillingford Crossing
Shillingford Crossing.trailhead: This trail connects Grandview Avenue, Dartmoor Court, and Pinecrest Drive neighborhoods with the Champlain Valley Expo in Essex (Between Route 15 and Pinecrest Drive).
Shillingford Crossing.features: Short, wooded trail connecting neighborhoods in Essex.

Warren Path.name: Warren Path
Warren Path.features: This is a wide, easy path through a beautiful hardwood forest studded with large, dramatic boulders and rock outcroppings.

More Green Mountain National Forest Trai.name: More Green Mountain National Forest Trails
More Green Mountain National Forest Trai.trailhead: Various locations throughout Addison, Washingon, and Rutland Counties.

Little Rock Pond.name: Little Rock Pond
Little Rock Pond.trailhead: From the intersection of US Route 7 and Brooklyn Road in Danby/Mt. Tabor take Brooklyn Road east (National Forest Road 10) for 3.2 miles to a paved parking lot on the right.  Start your hike near the sign board directly across the road from the parking lot.
Little Rock Pond.features: Visit one of the most beautiful and popular spots on the entire Long Trail.

Colchester Bog.name: Colchester Bog
Colchester Bog.trailhead: From Burlington, take Route 127 north for 5 miles. Bear left onto Porters Point Road near the drive-in theater. After 1.2 miles turn left on to Colchester Point Road. After a short drive, turn right into Colchester Airport Park. Park in the gravel lot. Walk across the ball field towards the cedar posts and the old runway. Follow the runway to a short trail into the woods and the beginning of the boardwalk. Cyclists and pedestrians can take the Burlington bikepath north to reach the bog.
Colchester Bog.features: Protected natural area accessible for viewing.

Mobbs Hill.name: Mobbs Hill
Mobbs Hill.trailhead:
From I-89 Exit 11:

Richmond/Williston Northbound Exit - Right at off ramp stop sign then immediate right on to Route 117 West.
Southbound Exit - Left at off ramp stop sign - go 0.2 miles then right on to Route 117 West.
Immediate right on to Governor Peck Road ( go 2.3 miles).
Left at stop sign on to Brown's Trace Road (go 0.1 miles).
Left on to Fitzsimonds Road (dirt PLEASE DRIVE SLOWLY!- go 0.8 miles). NOTE: Parking is extremely limited at the Fitzsimonds Rd. lot - 5 cars max.  Please park in a way that will accomodate others who arrive after you.  Do not block the travel lane on Fitzsimonds Rd. If the lot is full, please go elsewhere.
A kiosk with trail information about Mobb's Valley and Mobb's Hill below parking area.
Mobbs Hill.features: Large stands of pine and hemlock, mixed hardwood forest. Some open meadow, old apple trees, wrecked cars, steep ascents and descents, areas of exposure along ledgy outcroppings.

Bald Mountain, Pittsford.name: Bald Mountain, Pittsford
Bald Mountain, Pittsford.trailhead: Traveling South on Route 7, head north on Oxbow Road (directly across from Mobil Station on Route 7); Turn left on Adams Road; continue straight onto Furnace road at intersection with Goat Farm Road; at "Y" stay left on Barnard Road.
Bald Mountain, Pittsford.features: This short but sweet trail offers nice open views while crossing a meadow and wide open west/southwest views of Pittsford and surrounding areas.

Williams Woods Natural Area.name: Williams Woods Natural Area
Williams Woods Natural Area.trailhead: From Burlington take Route 7 south and at the stop light in Charlotte turn right at Ferry Road, which is also called F-5. Drive 0.3 mile to the stop sign. Turn left onto Greenbush Road, also called CR 22K. Drive two miles then veer left. Be careful at this intersection. Stay left on Greenbush Road as it continues (paved) to the south. (If you come to a railroad crossing, you've mistakenly turned off onto Thomsons Point Road.) Travel approximately one mile further on Greenbush until you come to a green Williams Woods sign and parking area on the right.
Williams Woods Natural Area.features: 63 acre natural area that includes a stand of mature valley clayplain forest, with 200+ year old oak trees.

Mount Abraham and Battell Trail.name: Mount Abraham and Battell Trail
Mount Abraham and Battell Trail.trailhead: About 14 miles northeast of Middlebury, in the town of Lincoln.
Mount Abraham and Battell Trail.features: A 5.8 mile round trip hike with alpine vegetation, an overnight shelter, and three-state mountain views. It's a vigorous hike up the western flank of Vermont's lowest 4,000 foot peak.

Mountain Views.name: Mountain Views
Mountain Views.trailhead: Jericho Elementary School, Route 15 in Jericho.
Mountain Views.features: Discover covered bridges and small farms within striking up-close views of Mt. Mansfield.

Rinker Steele Natural Area.name: Rinker Steele Natural Area
Rinker Steele Natural Area.trailhead:
Located off Route 10 north of Kendal and south of Fullington Farm and Wilson's Landing.
Head north from Hanover for approximately 2.5 miles. Continue 400 yards north of the Chieftain Motel where you'll find a blue and white "Rinker Tract" sign on the eaast side of Rte. 10. Pull off onto the shoulder. Trailhead located next to sign.
Rinker Steele Natural Area.features: Located in a mix of mature hardwood and softwood trees, the trail follows the edge of Rinker Pond, climbing upslope to the Quarry Loop and Hillside Trails. In 2008,  a new connector  trail linking the Storrs Pond recreation area was established.

Mills Riverside Trail.name: Mills Riverside Trail
Mills Riverside Trail.trailhead: Located directly off of VT Rt. 15 in the Town of Jericho, just Southwest of River Road
Mills Riverside Trail.features: A covered bridge, amazing views of Mt Mansfield, a pond and pavilion.

Cole Pond Trail.name: Cole Pond Trail
Cole Pond Trail.trailhead:
From Route 4, follow Rt 4A for 6.9 miles south turning right onto Bog Road. Trail parking located 2.0 miles ahead on right.
Bog Road is located 1.3 miles past the Shaker Hill Road intersection on Rt 4A.
Cole Pond Trail.features: Walk-in access to a 17 acre remote coldwater pond located in the Enfield Wildlife Management Area

Camel's Hump State Park.name: Camel's Hump State Park
Camel's Hump State Park.features: Camel's Hump is one of Vermont's highest mountain peaks, and easily the most recognizable by its double-humped profile.

Thundering Falls.name: Thundering Falls
Thundering Falls.trailhead:
From the intersection of Vermont Route 100 & Route 4 in Killington, drive 2 miles east to an intersection with River Road on the left.  From here drive 1.5 miles to a wheelchair accessible parking lot on the left.

From the intersection of Vermont Route 100 & Route 4 in Killington, drive 2.3 miles north on Vermont
Route 100 to an intersection with River Road on the right.    From here drive 2.5 miles to a wheelchair
accessible parking lot on the right.
Thundering Falls.features: Hike along a boardwalk and trail to the sixth tallest waterfall in Vermont.  At high water it is a magnificent 140 foot cascade through a steep and narrow cataract.

Riverside Avenue Path.name: Riverside Avenue Path
Riverside Avenue Path.trailhead: Path is accessible anywhere along Riverside Avenue. Its western terminus is at the Community Health Center; eastern terminus is at the Winooski River Bridge.
Riverside Avenue Path.features: Paved connection between the Old North End and Winooski. Some views of the Winooski River.

Oak Ridge Trail.name: Oak Ridge Trail
Oak Ridge Trail.trailhead: Trail head is in the Town of Ripton on Route 125.
Oak Ridge Trail.features: A day hike with views at the summit of Mt. Moosalamoo then a long descent along a ridge line.

Cycle the City.name: Cycle the City
Cycle the City.trailhead: Lake Champlain Ferry Dock, Downtown Burlington where King Street meets the lake.
Cycle the City.features: Varied route with views of Lake Champlain, Intervale farms and historic architecture all within Vermont's Queen City.

Montpelier - Wells River Rail Trail (Eas.name: Montpelier - Wells River Rail Trail (East Montpelier - Plainfield)
Montpelier - Wells River Rail Trail (Eas.trailhead: Public parking at Rte 14 trailhead, about 8/10 miles south of Jct Rte 14 and Rte 2 in East Montpelier.
Montpelier - Wells River Rail Trail (Eas.features: 2 miles of pleasant, gradual trail made from old railbed in quiet wooded setting.

Shelburne River Park.name: Shelburne River Park
Shelburne River Park.trailhead: From Shelburne Village, travel north on Route 7 over the bridge crossing the La Platte River. Immediately after the bridge, turn right onto Webster Road and after 50 yards, turn right and park next to the park. Portage canoes and kayaks across the park's grass picnic area to the river access launch site.
Shelburne River Park.features: Lake Champlain Land Trust Conservation Land--  Canoe and kayak to Lake Champlain.  Our convenient canoe and kayak launch is next to Route 7 just north of Shelburne Village.  La Platte River access to Lake Champlain with half hour flatwater paddle.

Deans Nature Preserve.name: Deans Nature Preserve
Deans Nature Preserve.trailhead: Heading North or South towards Poultney on Route 31, turn East onto Route 30. Head South on Route 30. Once past Lake St. Catherine State Park tak a quick left onto Endless Brook Road. Less than 1 mile down the dirt road will be a parking lot to your Right and 2 large Black Locust signs signifying the trailhead.
Deans Nature Preserve.features: A moderatly steep climb to the summit with an expansive view of Lake St. Catherine and mountains to the west. The trail farthest to the south is an easy swichtback pattern. The trail farthest to the north has exposed rock. Both are moderatly steep.

Volunteer Green Trail.name: Volunteer Green Trail
Volunteer Green Trail.trailhead: Take I89 South to Richmond exit, turn right after exit onto Rt 2. In Richmond, turn right at light onto Bridge Street and head south. Parking is in the Volunteer Green Park, which is on the right, just before the bridge over the Winooski. The trail begins near the river's edge.
Volunteer Green Trail.features: Views of the Winooski River, large stands of cottonwood.

Marsh-Billings Rockefeller National Hist.name: Marsh-Billings Rockefeller National Historical Park
Marsh-Billings Rockefeller National Hist.trailhead: From Woodstock go north on Route 12 for .6 miles. Turn right on River Rd and park in the visitor parking lot (immediately on the right).
Marsh-Billings Rockefeller National Hist.features:
Miles of scenic carriage roads and trails crisscross the gentle forested slopes of Mount Tom, one of the oldest professionally managed woodlands in America. Use of the trails is free and open to the public for walking, hiking, and horseback riding.

In the winter, trails are groomed for crosscountry skiing and snowshoeing by the Woodstock Inn & Resort Nordic Center (trail passes are required for winter use, call the Nordic Center at 802.457.6674)

Colchester Bayside to Village Path.name: Colchester Bayside to Village Path
Colchester Bayside to Village Path.trailhead: Bayside Park: Take exit 16 on I-89, Route 7 North, Left on Blakely Road (Route 127), Go 2.5 miles and Bayside park is on both sides of the road
Colchester Bayside to Village Path.features: Views of Lake Champlain. Part of the Champlain Bikeway. ADA Accessible. Beach at Bayside Park.

Wilgus State Park.name: Wilgus State Park
Wilgus State Park.features: Take in some great views of the scenic Connecticut River Valley from atop the Pinnacle or hike along the Connecticut River on a footpath loop south of the campsites.

Central Vermont Regional Path (Millstone.name: Central Vermont Regional Path (Millstone Hill West Section)
Central Vermont Regional Path (Millstone.features: The path goes in between playing fields, woods, schools, and ends past the Rock of Ages Museum.

Erwin Clifford Park Trail.name: Erwin Clifford Park Trail
Erwin Clifford Park Trail.trailhead: Travel on Route 14 west out of Hartford to Quechee/West Hartford Road. Turning onto that road, you will cross the White River via the West Hartford Bridge. Then turn left on Westfield Drive, and left again on Recreation Drive. Then follow the brown signs to Clifford Park. Parking: Public parking is available at the end of Recreation Drive in the parking lot.
Erwin Clifford Park Trail.features: Municipal park owned and maintained by the Town of Hartford Parks and Recreation Department.

Clinic.name: Clinic
Clinic.trailhead: Trail starts on Dana Hill Rd, but is commonly accessed from Tucker Hill Rd. Driving on Dana Hill Rd is not recommended, up from RT 17, it is very steep, wet, and lightly maintained.
Clinic.features: This Valley classic is a true "clinic of bike skills." Be careful to go right on Busternut soon after the double stream crossing to return to Dana Hill Rd. Stay on state land here, marked with orange blazes.

Mascoma River Greenway.name: Mascoma River Greenway
Mascoma River Greenway.trailhead:
Heading westbound on Mechanic St,, turn left onto Slayton Hill Rd., and take an immediate right onto mascoma St. Access this trail via a short packed gravel connector trail off Mascoma Street (just west of Slayton Hill Rd).
From High St. in Lebanon, continue south towards Mechanic St., immediately after passing Mascoma St., turn right onto the trail.
Mascoma River Greenway.features:
The Mascoma River Greenway (MRG) is envisioned as a 4-mile bicycle and pedestrian non-motorized, separated pathway connecting Lebanon with West Lebanon.
The former railway corridor used for the first mile of the MRG provides a wide and level treadway for trail users.

Pearl Street Park.name: Pearl Street Park
Pearl Street Park.trailhead: From Pearl St (Route 15) in Essex Junction, head West past the Champlain Valley EXPO but before Susie Wilson Road. The entrance to the park is at the traffic light at the intersection of Pearl Street and West Street Extension. Ample parking is available at this entrance.  Access by foot or bike is available from Warner Avenue and Kimberly Drive.
Pearl Street Park.features: Small network of trails connecting recreation fields and a playground.

Chipman Hill.name: Chipman Hill
Chipman Hill.trailhead: Access is from Springside St, High St. or from the TAM trailhead off of Seminary St. Extension, just east of the Co-operative Insurance building.

Busternut.name: Busternut
Busternut.features:
Generally ridden as a climb from the Clinic. After big stream crossing on Clinic, stay right and traverse, before climbing again. Climb tops out on Dana Hill Rd.

From Dana Hill Rd. stay left at the intersection near the top and look on your left for the entrance before a big stone wall.

Niquette Bay State Park.name: Niquette Bay State Park
Niquette Bay State Park.trailhead: From Exit 17 of Interstate 89, go west on U.S. Route 2 approximately one mile. Take the Raymond Road exit (a right turn then left to cross the highway). On Raymond Road, watch for the park entrance on your left. This State Park charges a day-use fee during the operagting season (Memorial Day Weekend through Labor Day), but the park is open year-round. The area can also be accessed by boat (please do not tie up to trees)
Niquette Bay State Park.features: Vermont State Parks in partnership with the Lake Champlain Land Trust.  Family-friendly trails with beautiful outcrops and many high-elevation views.  The perfect location for a family hike -- park and walk down an old road to the sandy, natural shores of Lake Champlain. With an extensive trail network, Niquette Bay State Park is the perfect place to boat, swim, hike, snowshoe, cross-country ski, or picnic. The park is dog-friendly, with an off-leash loop as one of your hiking options.

Fairfax Recreational Trail.name: Fairfax Recreational Trail
Fairfax Recreational Trail.trailhead:
From I-89, take Exit #18 (Georgia Ctr./Fairfax)
Turn Right on Ethan Allen Hwy. (US-7) - go 0.20.3 mi
Turn Left on Highbridge Rd. (VT-104A) - go 4.57.3 mi
Bear Right on Main St. (VT-104) - go 1.42.3 mi
Turn Right on Hunt St. - go 0.40.6 mi
Parking on the Left
Fairfax Recreational Trail.features: A mix of easy paved and unpaved trails through recreation fields, natural areas and historic sites.

Catamount Trail.name: Catamount Trail
Catamount Trail.trailhead: Numerous trailheads; in Chittenden County, these are in Bolton and Huntington. See map for specific locations.
Catamount Trail.features: A unique 300-mile, winter-use trail open to the public for skiing and snowshoeing, following remote wilderness routes, groomed cross-country ski trails, snowmobile trails, and old logging roads. Winter use only.

Allen Point Access Area.name: Allen Point Access Area
Allen Point Access Area.trailhead: From I-89: Take Exit 17. Go west on Route 2 for 8 miles to South Hero Village. Turn left onto South Street and go 2.5 miles. Turn right on to Martin Road and go 0.3 of a mile. The Allen Point Access Area is on the left. There are two parking areas - one at Martin Road and another for anglers 0.7 miles down the Access Area. Visitors who are not using the Access Area to fish should only park at the upper lot by Martin Road.
Allen Point Access Area.features: A scenic trail offering great lake access. Good fishing at "the cut" in the causeway. Bikers are encouraged to park at the lot immediately adjacent to the road. There is a port-o-let right at the beginning of the old causeway.

Airport Park.name: Airport Park
Airport Park.trailhead: Coming from Burlington, take Rt. 127 to Porter's Point Rd. Turn left and travel 1.25 miles. Turn left again onto Airport Rd. The parking lot is 0.5 mile down the road, very visible on your right.
Airport Park.features: Playground, basketball court, baseball field, and the historic Log Schoolhouse Information Center and Museum.

Parcel 5 Multi Use Trail.name: Parcel 5 Multi Use Trail
Parcel 5 Multi Use Trail.trailhead: From Main St. Norwich, turn left on Beaver Meadow Rd. Follow for 2.5 miles, then turn right at a small sign "5" for the entry to the ample parking lot.
Parcel 5 Multi Use Trail.features: Designed as a 5K loop for mountain biking, hiking, running or cross-country skiing in season, this is a meandering path through a variety of woodlands with some steep ups and downs. Although generously wide as mountain bike trail, there are some difficult water bars. With ever-changing snow conditions it is a challenging ski trail in winter. A trail map with elevations is posted at a kiosk at the parking lot.

Hurricane Forest Wildlife Refuge Trails.name: Hurricane Forest Wildlife Refuge Trails
Hurricane Forest Wildlife Refuge Trails.trailhead: Take Rte 5 South from White River Junction past the VA hospital. Take an immediate right after the I-89 overpass onto Wright Reservoir Rd; parking is at the pullover just a few feet before the refuge entrance on Wright Reservoir Rd.

Shelburne Bay Park.name: Shelburne Bay Park
Shelburne Bay Park.trailhead: From Route 7, turn east onto Bay Road. Go under the railroad tracks and look for the trailhead on your right, just past the boat access.
Shelburne Bay Park.features: Nice jogging and hiking trails offer beach access and views of Shelburne Bay.

Missisquoi Valley Rail Trail.name: Missisquoi Valley Rail Trail
Missisquoi Valley Rail Trail.trailhead: Connects St. Albans to Richford, passing through Enosburg Falls, East Berkshire, Fairfield, Sheldon and Swanton.
Missisquoi Valley Rail Trail.features: Whether you walk, ski, or ride, a trip on the Missisquoi Valley Rail Trail takes you into the heart of Northern Vermont's agricultural open lands. The Trail wanders through the farms, forests, fields, and wetlands of Franklin County at a railroad's pace - slow, steady grades with sweeping bends. For the full length of the Trail, you'll see the postcard images of Vermont you've grown to love. You'll also see the families and working landscapes that created and support this spectacular scenery. Also open for snowmobiling in winter.

Mud Pond Country Park.name: Mud Pond Country Park
Mud Pond Country Park.trailhead: From Williston Village, head South on Oak Hill Road. After passing over the highway, turn left onto South Road. Continue on South Road for 2 miles and turn right onto Mud Pond Road. A small parking area is available on Mud Pond Road. Please do not park on South Road. From the parking area, backtrack on South Road 0.1 miles till you see a small wooden bridge over the drainage ditch, on your right with yellow sign/ black arrow at trailhead.
Mud Pond Country Park.features:
This designated natural area consists of 79 acres and offers a 2.3 mile round trip multiple use trail open to non-motorized travel.  This area connects to the Five Tree Hill and Mud Pond Conservation Area.  Parking is available on Mud Pond Road.
Bike trails established by Fellowship of the Wheel offer Beginner to Advanced-Intermediate single track.

Battell Woods.name: Battell Woods
Battell Woods.trailhead: Parking area for Battell & Means Woods is on Seminary St. Extension, east of the village of Middlebury, or east of Route 7 south of the village.
Battell Woods.features: Part of the Trail Around Middlebury

Mobbs Valley.name: Mobbs Valley
Mobbs Valley.trailhead:
- From I-89 Exit 11 (Richmond/Williston)
- Northbound Exit: Right at off ramp stop sign then immediate right on to Route 117 West.
- Southbound Exit: Left at off ramp stop sign - go 0.2 miles then right on to Route 117 West.
- Immediate right on to Governor Peck Road (go 2.3 miles).
- Left at stop sign on to Brown's Trace Road (go 0.1 miles).
- Left on to Fitzsimonds Road (dirt PLEASE DRIVE SLOWLY!- go 0.8 miles).
- Parking area on left.  NOTE: Parking is extremely limited at the Fitzsimonds Rd. lot - 5 cars max.  Please park in a way that will accomodate others who arrive after you.  Do not block the travel lane on Fitzsimonds Rd. If the lot is full, please go elsewhere.
- A kiosk with trail information below parking area. Updated maps and signage is in the works.
Mobbs Valley.features: Variable terrain, expansive meadows, dense hemlock woods, open hardwood forest overlooking Mill Brook. 5 ravine bridges built by VYCC and a wonderful swimming hole!

Holt's Ledge.name: Holt's Ledge
Holt's Ledge.trailhead: Take Route 10 north from Hanover into Lyme. Coming around the green in Lyme, bear right at the white church onto Dorchester Rd, follow signs for the Dartmouth Skiway. After passing through Lyme Center 1.8 miles from the Lyme green, the road winds around for another 1.3 miles before reaching a fork in the road . Turn right and continue to park in the Dartmouth Skiway’s lot (during winter an area may be established for non-skiers to park in order to make it easier for the staff there to see if anyone is still on the mountain). Walk back to the fork and head left into the woods on the Appalachian Trail.

Chaffee Wildlife Sanctuary.name: Chaffee Wildlife Sanctuary
Chaffee Wildlife Sanctuary.trailhead: From Lyme Village, drive north 1.8 miles on Route 10, past the entrance to Post Pond. The Sanctuary is identified with a large sign on the left (west) side of the road. Park off the shoulder. Trails are marked with orange and aluminum markers.
Chaffee Wildlife Sanctuary.features: The Town of Lyme acquired its very first wildlife preserve in 1977 from Guy and Esther Nichols, with the help of the federal Land & Water Conservation Fund and donations from many Lyme families. The sanctuary protects 21 acres of grassland and riparian (stream-side) habitat along Trout Brook, which flows into Post Pond, 450' of frontage on Post Pond, and Clay Brook, which flows out of the pond and on to the Connecticut River. In 2000 the CC added 2 acres at the mouth of Pinnacle Brook, just south of the pond's public boat access.

Winooski Nature Trail.name: Winooski Nature Trail
Winooski Nature Trail.trailhead: From the roundabout in Winooski, turn onto East Allen Street (Route 15 East). The parking lot and trailhead are just off East Allen Street, 200' west of the railroad tracks.
Winooski Nature Trail.features: Nature close to home, wildflowers, scenic views and fishing

Dorset Park.name: Dorset Park
Dorset Park.trailhead: Take Williston Road (Rte. 2) east, then turn right onto Dorset Street. Turn left onto Swift Street extension, and park in the lot at right.
Dorset Park.features: Pleasant hikes through woods and fields with nice views of the Green Mountains.

Lake Champlain Loop.name: Lake Champlain Loop
Lake Champlain Loop.features: This is a classic Champlain Valley almost century ride, with beautiful views, relatively gentle terrain and a ferry ride back to Burlington to finish the day. Be sure to check the Port Kent Ferry schedule before planning your ride. http://www.ferries.com/crossing-schedule-rates/burlington-to-port-kent-ferry.

Enchanted Forest.name: Enchanted Forest
Enchanted Forest.trailhead: From Waitsfield, take RT 17 to Tucker Hill Rd. Up Tucker Hill Rd to small parking area on left, near the end of the road. Map and trailhead in parking lot.
Enchanted Forest.features: A really fun beautiful trail with great access, one of the Mad River Valley classics.

Northern Rail Trail.name: Northern Rail Trail
Northern Rail Trail.trailhead: Parking is available in downtown Lebanon along Taylor Street (in front of the CCBA), and in the two lots behind Lebanon City Hall. Additional parking is available near the trail gate east of Packard Hill Covered Bridge on Riverside Drive. Parking is also available at other trailheads along this route, such as Ice House Road off Route 4 (Near Mobil station.) The major trailheads are plowed and accessible in the winter.
Northern Rail Trail.features: A nearly flat trail beginning at Lebanon, New Hampshire, in the Mascoma River Valley, passing though historic villages and by scenic lakes, streams and hills along the old railroad bed of the Boston & Maine Railroad Northern Line.

Mathieu Town Forest.name: Mathieu Town Forest
Mathieu Town Forest.trailhead: Access to this trail is via the Sand Hill Park trail at the eastern end of the forest. To get there, take Route 15 east to Sand Hill Road. After 0.1 mile, turn right at the park entrance. Ample parking is available at Sand Hill Park.
Mathieu Town Forest.features: Thick woods with a network of winding trails over varied terrain.

Whales Tails Walking Path.name: Whales Tails Walking Path
Whales Tails Walking Path.trailhead: From Burlington, take Williston Road (Rte. 2) east out of town, towards Williston. Turn right onto Kennedy Drive (a left turn here will bring you to the airport), then take a left onto Kimball Ave. Take the second right onto Community Drive; the trailhead will be on your right as you round the curve.
Whales Tails Walking Path.features: Whales' tails, in New England's only landlocked state.

Brownway River Trail.name: Brownway River Trail
Brownway River Trail.trailhead: There are two trailheads. On the week-end, park at the Elementary School parking lot and follow a  trail entrance along the southeast boundary of the Village Garage, or at  the  Main entrance on Missisquoi St. across from Missisquoi Cemetery.  There is an interpretive trail map at the Elementary School entrance.
Brownway River Trail.features: The Brownway River Trail follows the Mississquoi River for about a mile, through fields, forests and floodplains.

Farnum Trails.name: Farnum Trails
Farnum Trails.trailhead:
From Route 120 in Meriden, NH, turn west at the yellow flashing light onto Main Street and go 0.8 miles, over the hill past Kimball Union Academy (KUA) and down to a covered bridge. Turn left onto Colby Hill Road, going through the covered bridge.
Farnum Trailhead: From the covered bridge go 0.9 mile on Colby Hill Road and turn left onto Columbus Jordan Road. Parking will be on your right along Columbus Jordan Road, half a mile from its junction with Colby Hill Road. The blue-blazed Farnum Loop Trail enters the woods about 25 yards from the parking area across a mowed field to the west. On the other side of the road, to the east, is a yellow-blazed connector trail that links with the French’s Ledges Trail, bringing you to the Ledges in just over three-quarters of a mile. .
Farnum Trails.features: Provides a wide variety of trails to suit many abilities.

Central Vermont Regional Path (Montpelie.name: Central Vermont Regional Path (Montpelier Bike Path)
Central Vermont Regional Path (Montpelie.trailhead:
Start at intersection of Stone Cutter's Way and Granite Street or
Start at the other end on Junction Road just past the intersection with Dog River Road.
Central Vermont Regional Path (Montpelie.features: Pave bike path follows Winooski River at times and connects Montpelier High School to the downtown.  There is a wonderful little park/garden along the trail known as "Peace Park".

Backwater Trail.name: Backwater Trail
Backwater Trail.trailhead:
Travel on Route 5 to a pullout just north of Wilder Village. There is a sign on the side of the parking lot marking it as Maanawaka Conservation Area. Park in front of the gate on the pull out at Dothan Brook.
Please be careful not to block the gate.
Backwater Trail.features: A great out and back trail on its own or to add more distance to a hike on the Hazen Trail.

Rossetti Natural Area.name: Rossetti Natural Area
Rossetti Natural Area.trailhead:
By Bike: Follow Island Line Trail north. Take a right onto Colchester Point Road and follow to the Rossetti Natural Area parking area on the left side.
By Car: From I-89 take Exit 15 in Winooski. Turn left at the end of the ramp onto Route 15. In downtown Winooski go through the traffic light onto Malletts Bay Avenue. Follow this until the intersection with Route 127. Follow 127 N to the "T" intersection, with Holy Cross Road to your left and Lakeshore Drive to the right. At this junction, the property is directly in front of you.
Rossetti Natural Area.features: Lake Champlain Land Trust Conservation Project in partnership with the Town of Colchester and Colchester Land Trust.  Easy, family-friendly walk on wide trail to wetland boardwalk and sandy Lake Champlain beach.  Great location for an easy walk, viewing turtles, frogs and other wetland species from boardwalk, and a refreshing swim in Lake Champlain.

Big Rock Nature Area.name: Big Rock Nature Area
Big Rock Nature Area.trailhead:
From the east: The trail-head is located on the west side of Market Street, 1/8 mile south of Lyme Common, at a blue sign near a group of mailboxes. Please be courteous to residents when parking.

From the west: The trail-head is located on the east side of Route 10, 1/4 mile south of Lyme School, and just above a bridge over the brook. Trails are marked with reflective orange and aluminum disks.
Big Rock Nature Area.features: This 23-acre preserve behind Lyme Village was created in 1998 with a gift of ten acres to the Town from Amalia Greenwood, Ralph & Lillian Bircher, and Beverly & Earl Strout, and of the remainder from Paul& Veronica Guyre to the Upper Valley Land Trust in 2002. The preserve protects the northern corridor of Grant Brook and a large wetland behind the Common. A gentle half-mile of the Grant Brook Trail runs through the preserve and continues down to the river, via Lyme School, and up to Lyme Center Academy, from the Market Street bridge.

Muddy Brook Park.name: Muddy Brook Park
Muddy Brook Park.trailhead:
From Route 15 in Colchester, turn onto Lime Kiln Road. Take the second left after Lime Kiln Bridge onto National Guard Ave. Follow 1.5 miles onto Poor Farm Road. The parking lot is on the left.
From South Burlington, take Route 2 east, past the highway. Turn left onto White Street. Then turn left onto Airport Parkway and follow for 1.3 miles. Turn right onto National Guard Ave. Follow 1.5 miles onto Poor Farm Road. The parking lot is on the left.
Muddy Brook Park.features: Lush ferns, scenic woodlands and meadows, ideal for youngsters.

Town House Trail.name: Town House Trail
Town House Trail.features: The Town House Trail runs from the village of Strafford near the Town House to the highest point on Rt 132 on O'Neill Road.

South Burlington Rec Path.name: South Burlington Rec Path
South Burlington Rec Path.trailhead: This path network can be accessed at many points throughout the city.
South Burlington Rec Path.features: Access to unusual spots throughout South Burlington from unexpected places. Beautiful off-road path - lots to explore.

Huntington Center River Path.name: Huntington Center River Path
Huntington Center River Path.trailhead:
From the center of Richmond, turn at the traffic light onto Bridge St, follow past the Round Church, and stay on the main road which takes a sharp right curve after the church. Huntington Village is about 7 miles down this road.  Continue through town. Go about 3 miles to the next town,which is Huntington Center. There are 2 places to park.
1) Brewster-Pierce School: take a left onto Camel's Hump Road in the middle of town, and then take the next right to the school parking lot. The trail starts on the far side of the playground.
2) Huntington Recreation Park: past Camel's Hump Rd., you'll see the Fire Station on the right; take a right just after it. Follow to the parking area at the end of this road (the road is actually part of the trail from the school).
Huntington Center River Path.features: A short trail that follows the Huntington River and a small feeder stream, with mountain views including Camel's Hump Mountain.

Leffert's Pond Loop.name: Leffert's Pond Loop
Leffert's Pond Loop.trailhead: From the intersection of US Route 7 and US Route 4 east in Rutland go east on Route 4 for 4.0 miles to Meadow Lake Drive.  Turn left onto Meadow Lake Drive for 1.7 miels to its end at Chittenden Road.  Turn right onto Chittendent Road for 2.9 miels where it becomes Dam Road.  Continue on Dam Road for 1.4 miles to Wildcat Road.  Bear right onto Wildcat Road for 0.9 miels to a gateway on the left.  Turn left through the gate and proceed 0.5 miels to the parking lot.
Leffert's Pond Loop.features: A pleasant leisurely walk around Lefferts Pond in Chittenden; cross wooden footbridges, past an old milldam, with a good chance of seeing a moose if you go early in the morning!  Points of interest include:  remains of an old lodge and an old milldam.

Green Mountain Audubon Center.name: Green Mountain Audubon Center
Green Mountain Audubon Center.trailhead: All trails can be accessed from the Sugarhouse Parking Area on the Huntington Rd. or the Office/Education Barn parking lot on Sherman Hollow Rd. Trail head signs and yellow markers on the longer trails help to keep users on track.
Green Mountain Audubon Center.features: Enjoy bird watching and wildlife tracking along this relaxing hiking trail network.

Route 127 Path.name: Route 127 Path
Route 127 Path.trailhead:
This trail may be accessed off the eastern end of Manhattan Drive deep in Burlington's Old North End, at the northern corner of St. Louis St. At this end, the trail drops straight down into the intervale, below Route 127, then slowly climbs back up to the level of Route 127.
The trail may also be accessed from the northern end of Ethan Allen Parkway in Burlington's New North End. Two other trailheads may be found in Ethan Allen Park and from Ethan Allen Homestead. There is plenty of parking in both of those locations.
Route 127 Path.features: Sweeping views of the Intervale and Winooski River from this off road connection parallel to North Avenue and Route 127. Closure Notice: Due to erosion, a significant section of this path has been closed between WVPD/Ethan Allen Homestead and Ethan Allen Parkway. Closed portions are highlighted in yellow on the map. Users traveling from the Old North End will not be able to connect to the New North End via this route. Alternative routes should be sought, including the Waterfront Bikepath and/or North Avenue.

Rena Calkins Trail.name: Rena Calkins Trail
Rena Calkins Trail.trailhead: From Riverside Avenue in the north end of Burlington, take Intervale Rd. down into the Intervale.  Trailhead is at the parking lot just past Gardener's Supply.
Rena Calkins Trail.features: Short trail in Burlington's intervale, close to the Winooski River and near farms; this is a trail with a rural character right in the heart of the city.

Chandler Ridge and Leicester Hollow.name: Chandler Ridge and Leicester Hollow
Chandler Ridge and Leicester Hollow.trailhead: From Route 73, take Hathaway Rd to Flora White Rd to Silver Lake Rd. Trailhead at end of Silver Lake Rd.
Chandler Ridge and Leicester Hollow.features: Newly opened multi-use trail in the Green Mountain National Forest, in partnership with the Vermont Mountain Bike Association.

Eagle Mountain.name: Eagle Mountain
Eagle Mountain.trailhead: From Burlington: Take I-89 north to Exit 17. Go  west on Route 2 for 2.4 miles.  Turn right onto Bear Trap Road. After 1.8 miles the road forks.  Bear left toward barn.  At the stop sign turn left onto Cadreact Road.  Follow north approximately 2.5 miles.  The road becomes Beebee Road.  Turn left onto Cold Spring Road one-tenth of a mile to the parking area on the right.  Ths road is private please do not go further than the Natural Area.
Eagle Mountain.features: Lake Champlain Land Trust Conservation Land-- Easy family hikes with rewarding views of Lake Champlain, South Hero, and the Adirondacks. 25 minutes from Burlington.  In addition to the Hoyt Overlook Trail, other trails include a hike to the top of Eagle Mountain.   Most of the seven trails are 10 to 25 minute loops.

White Rocks.name: White Rocks
White Rocks.trailhead: From US 7 in Wallingford, follow Vt. 140 east.  Turn south onto Sugar Hill Road (2.3 miles) then turn right onto White Rocks Picnic Road (USFS Road 52) (2.4 miels), and continue to the picnic area and parking (3.0 miles).
White Rocks.features: This trail links the White Rocks Picnic Area with the Long Trail, which leads to the summit of White Rocks Mountain and White Rocks Cliff.

CCBA Riverwalk.name: CCBA Riverwalk
CCBA Riverwalk.trailhead:
Trailhead is located at the edge of CCBA's back parking area and near a large picnic shelter (pavilion).





Traveling South on I-89
Take Exit 18 for Hanover/Lebanon, New Hampshire. Turn right at the traffic  light at the end of the exit ramp. Follow route 120 for one-quarter  mile to a stop sign, staying in the left lane. At the stop sign, turn left  following Route 120 as it curves left into the Downtown Business District of Lebanon  and passes Colburn Park. With the Lebanon Post Office straight ahead, bear left  around the park, then proceed straight down Campbell Street. The Carter  Community Building is on the right at 1 Campbell Street. Bear right,  then take your first left. Straight ahead is the main parking lot for the  Witherell Recreation Center, and the building is on the  left. Proceed to back of CCBA to park and access trail.
CCBA Riverwalk.features: This 5' wide trail begins from the back parking area at CCBA's Witherell Recreation Center and follows the Mascoma River, passing playground and recreational facilities along the way.

Gile Mountain Trail.name: Gile Mountain Trail
Gile Mountain Trail.trailhead: From Main St., Norwich, continue west out of the village and past Beaver Meadow Rd. for 0.5 miles. Turn left onto Turnpike Rd. and continue for 5.3 miles to the trailhead parking area on left. While traveling on Turnpike Rd., stay left at New Boston Rd. and Upper Turnpike Rd. intersections which are located 1.0 and 2.7 miles from Main Street. When you drive under the powerline corridor you’ll be 0.7 miles from the parking area.
Gile Mountain Trail.features: Two trail options are provided for Gile Mountain: a 0.68 mile hiking trail and a longer switch-backed ski/bike trail. Elevation gain to the summit ridge and fire tower observation area is 413 ft.

Red Rocks Park.name: Red Rocks Park
Red Rocks Park.trailhead: From Shelburne Road (Route 7) in South Burlington just south of the intersection with 189, turn west onto Queen City Parkway. After 0.5 mile, turn left onto Central Avenue. The parking area and park entrance will be visible on your right.
Red Rocks Park.features: Forested foot trails emerge onto rocky shoreline with spectacular views of Lake Champlain and Shelburne Bay.

Grand Isle State Park.name: Grand Isle State Park
Grand Isle State Park.trailhead:
From the South:
Take I-89 to Exit 17; Travel west on US Route 2 through the towns of South Hero and Keeler Bay.  Continue straight through the flashing light at the junction of US Route 2 and VT Route 314.  The park access road is exactly 2 miles past the light on the right side of the road;  Follow access road to East Shore Road South, approximately 0.75 mile. Park at the corner of East Shore Road South.
From the North:
Travel East on US Route 2 through the Champlain Islands.  Drive through the towns of Alburgh, North Hero and Grand Isle.  The park entrance is approximately 2.5 miles on the left after the flashing light in Grand Isle village.
The park access road between US 2 and East Shore South is closed to vehicles from mid-November to mid-May, during which period off-season hikers may access the park entrance and trailhead along East Shore South via either Town Line Road to the south, or Donaldson Road to the north
Grand Isle State Park.features: A short hike in Grand Isle State Park, this trail features a tower that once had a view of the lake, but is now mostly obscured by trees.  An easy hike in the midst of woods, giving a nice natural feel to the trail. An interesting geological feature is an exposed bedrock dome with deep fissures, which you will cross approximately 2/3 of the way around the loop.

Happy Hill - Appalachian Trail - Cossing.name: Happy Hill - Appalachian Trail - Cossingham Road Loop Trail
Happy Hill - Appalachian Trail - Cossing.trailhead:
Park at the end of the maintained part of Happy Hill Rd.
Please do not block access.

Reset odometer at each intersection.
From Dan & Whit’s General Store on Main Street, Norwich head north:
0.02 miles, left onto Beaver Meadow Rd.
0.44 miles, left onto Bragg Hill Rd.
1.35 miles, left onto Happy Hill Rd.
0.54 miles, park at Happy Hill Trailhead. Please do not block access to the active driveway.
Happy Hill - Appalachian Trail - Cossing.features: A loop path for hiking part of the Appalachian Trail.

Paradise Park.name: Paradise Park
Paradise Park.trailhead: I-91 Hartland exit 9, take VT 12/US Rte 5 south into Windsor (3.8 miles). Take a right at the traffic light onto State St. and continue .7 miles to County Rd. Take another right on County Rd. towards the hospital and follow this for 0.2 miles. At the bottom of a short hill watch for the parking area for Paradise Park on your right. If you reach the hospital on your left you have just missed the park! Walk-in trail access is also available from Eddie’s Place and Runnemede Lane, near the Price Chopper grocery store located on VT 12/US Rte 5 just before the downtown area.
Paradise Park.features:
Various short loops through mature forests, fields and along stream with access to the beauty surrounding the shores of Lake Runnemede.
Numerous benches and picnic areas.

River Walk to Salmon Hole.name: River Walk to Salmon Hole
River Walk to Salmon Hole.trailhead: Access from Intervale Road, south of railroad tracks, or from Salmon Hole trailhead.
River Walk to Salmon Hole.features: Trail along the Winooski River from Intervale Road to the Salmon Hole.

VINS Nature Center Trails.name: VINS Nature Center Trails
VINS Nature Center Trails.trailhead:
From Woodstock, VT drive east on Route 4 for 6 miles, turn left at VINS Nature Center access road (there is a large sign and flag pole).
From White River Junction and points east, take Exit 1 off Interstate 89 and head west for 3.5 miles. The VINS Nature Center is on the right 1/4 mile past the Quechee Gorge.
Trailhead is near the raptor enclosures.
VINS Nature Center Trails.features:
In addition to a network of forested trails, VINS has many exciting exhibits.  Exhibits are located throughout the VINS Nature Center and focus on topics such as Insects, Vermont Meadows, Bird Rehabilitation, and the Importance of Wetlands.  The most popular exhibit showcases our ambassador non-releasable raptors.
VINS also offers extraordinary educational programs and nature camps.  For more information, speak with someone at the Nature Store or visit www.vinsweb.org

Upper LaPlatte River Natural Area.name: Upper LaPlatte River Natural Area
Upper LaPlatte River Natural Area.trailhead:
From downtown Burlington, take Rt. 7 south approx. 9 miles.  From Shelburne Village follow Route 7 south past
Shelburne Museum to the light at the top of  the hill, turn left (east) onto Marsett Road. Follow straight through a stop sign (now Falls Road) until just after the bridge over the La Platte River Waterfalls; turn right immediately after the bridge onto Thomas Road. Follow Thomas Road up the hill and after it bends east, turn into the first marked driveway entrance of  the Vermont Zen Center (480 Thomas Road).  Find marked parking spot within the Center’s parking area and follow trail signs to the beginning of  the trail.
Upper LaPlatte River Natural Area.features: Upper LaPlatte River Natural Area is perfect for a family hike, picnic, cross-country ski or snowshoe.

Lower Slade Brook Trail.name: Lower Slade Brook Trail
Lower Slade Brook Trail.trailhead: Take River Road north from Route 10.  The property is on the right hand side 0.6 miles from the intersection with Route 10.  Limited parking is available at the River Road trailhead.
Lower Slade Brook Trail.features: The trail at Slade Brook has easy terrain.  The wooded path follows the meandering brook up to a waterfall, one of the property's notable features.  Currently connections to other trails in the area are not maintained.

Silver Lake.name: Silver Lake
Silver Lake.trailhead: East side of Lake Dunmore near Goshen, Route 53.
Silver Lake.features: The hike is over 5 miles round trip, but the elevation gain is minimal. The trail shares the same approach as Mount Mossalamoo for the first mile, but after that it is an entirely different hiking experience taking you to a pristine lake with an interesting past.

Bolton Valley Resort.name: Bolton Valley Resort
Bolton Valley Resort.trailhead:
Bolton Valley Access Road.
Note  Trails are for seasonal use (snow activities only).  Anyone accessing the groomed trails or Catamount Trail, the Bolton/Trapps  Trail, or accessing Cotton Brook in winter must purchase a trail pass  from Bolton.
Bolton Valley Resort.features: All kinds of activities, including downhill skiing, nordic skiing, telemark, snowboarding, and snowshoeing. Rentals available. Lodging and dining also available. Lessons offered on an individual or group basis.

Wallingford Pond.name: Wallingford Pond
Wallingford Pond.trailhead: From the intersection of US Route 7 and VT Route 140 at the stop light in Wallingford Village take Route 140 east for 2.3 miles; bear right onto Sugar Hill Road for 1.7 miles; turn right onto Forest Road 20 for 2.3 miles to a trailhead sign on the left near the end of the drivable road.  Park on the left.  Start your hike behind the trailhead sign.
Wallingford Pond.features: An easy walk to good-sized body of water.

Charlotte Park and Wildlife Refuge.name: Charlotte Park and Wildlife Refuge
Charlotte Park and Wildlife Refuge.trailhead: From Burlington, take Route 7 south approximately 10 miles. Take a right on Nursery Rd. Travel about 1 mile and turn right on Greenbush Rd. Travel 1 mile and parking is on your right.
Charlotte Park and Wildlife Refuge.features: Hiking trails through diverse woodlands and wetlands as well as pastures and meadows. Gravel trails for passive recreation that wind through 95 acres of agricultural lands.

Fort Ethan Allen Parade Grounds & Park.name: Fort Ethan Allen Parade Grounds & Park
Fort Ethan Allen Parade Grounds & Park.trailhead: From Rt 15, turn onto Ethan Allen Avenue. Bear left onto Dalton Drive, which borders the park. On-street parking is available all along Dalton Drive.
Fort Ethan Allen Parade Grounds & Park.features: Large green featuring athletic fields and a one mile loop trail.

East Woods.name: East Woods
East Woods.trailhead: From Main Street in Burlington take Spear Street south for 1.1 miles. At the traffic light turn right onto Swift Street. Look for the East Woods sign 0.2 miles on the right, cars can be parked here at the small pull-off area on the right. The trail system begins just behind the sign with the interpretive trail heading to the left just after entering the woods.

Green Mountain Trails.name: Green Mountain Trails
Green Mountain Trails.trailhead: Located 8  miles north of Killington on route 100 across from Amee Farm Lodge. From  Route 89 follow 107 south to Route 100 and continue 3 miles. Look for  the giant wooden mtn. bike tire.
Green Mountain Trails.features: A growing network of singletrack trails for all abilities, passing by mountain streams and overlooks, with a beguiling panorama of The Green Mountains and pastoral valley at the summit that can't be missed.

Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site.name: Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site
Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site.trailhead:
Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site is located off NH Route 12A just 1.5 miles north of the Cornish-Windsor covered bridge.
Alternatively, from I-89 Exit 20, head south on route 12A for 11.4 miles to Saint-Gaudens Road. Turn left and proceed upslope for 0.3 miles to parking lot on right.
Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site.features: Visit this 190-acre National Historic Site to view beautiful sculptures created by one of America's greatest sculptors, Augustus Saint-Gaudens. Fascinating history and very well kept gardens abound. Explore the park's natural areas on two very interesting trails featuring a variety of wildlife habitats. The 1/4 mile Ravine Trail features a shady eastern hemlock forest accompanied by many species of ferns and wildflowers. Blow-Me Down Trail will guide you on a 1 1/2 mile roundtrip to a wetland boardwalk and the historic Blow-Me-Down Mill. The richness of habitats often provide for some great viewing of many wildlife and bird species along the way.

Cyclone and Cyclone Connector.name: Cyclone and Cyclone Connector
Cyclone and Cyclone Connector.features: Cyclone Connector (.5 miles) is moderate, Cyclone (2 miles) is difficult.

Centennial Woods.name: Centennial Woods
Centennial Woods.trailhead: From Main Street in Burlington, head north on East Avenue. Turn right onto Carrigan Drive follow to the end. The parking lot and trailhead are at the end of the drive. You'll also find a trailhead along Carrigan Drive if arriving by foot.
Centennial Woods.features: 65 acres of mature conifer stands, mixed hardwoods, fields, streams, and wetlands.

Pittsford Recreation Area Trails.name: Pittsford Recreation Area Trails
Pittsford Recreation Area Trails.features: Trail system within the town of Pittsford.  Trails cut through woodslands, open meadows, and pine groves.

Cole Brook Trail, Benson Town Forest.name: Cole Brook Trail, Benson Town Forest
Cole Brook Trail, Benson Town Forest.trailhead: From the flashing light on Route 120 in Meriden, turn onto Main Street. Go one mile to reach High Street. Turn right and continue to the end of the dirt road where you'll find a small road shoulder parking area. Parking available only during the non-snow season. Follow Cram Hill Road until you reach sign for Cole Brook Trail on right.
Cole Brook Trail, Benson Town Forest.features: The Cole Brook Trail is located on the Benson Town Forest and connects the Moulton Trail to Cram Hill Road (Class VI Rd.).

Geprags Park Trails.name: Geprags Park Trails
Geprags Park Trails.trailhead:
From Hinesburg Town Hall, go North on Route 116 for 0.8 miles. At the traffic light, turn left onto Shelburne Falls Road. Follow Shelburne Falls Road for 0.5 miles. The parking area for Geprags Park is on the right. The trailhead is located a few yards up the hill from the parking area.
Note - this is the only access point!  (No access from Route 116 to the Lupine Spur Trail -  private property!)
Geprags Park Trails.features: Over two miles of foot trails on conserved public land.

Winooski Gorge Natural Area.name: Winooski Gorge Natural Area
Winooski Gorge Natural Area.trailhead:
From Saint Michael's College on VT Route 15, turn onto Lime Kiln Road. Parking is on right just after the bridge.
Trail can also be accessed on the other side from S. Burlington via Airport Parkway or National Guard Ave. Take either of these roads to the north/northwest, they merge and flow onto Lime Kiln Rd. Parking is on left before the bridge.
Winooski Gorge Natural Area.features: Observation area. History of Lime Kiln Bridge.

Trowbridge Crossing.name: Trowbridge Crossing
Trowbridge Crossing.trailhead: From Route 15 in Essex, 1.5 miles from 289, proceed straight at the intersection with Browns River Road. Turn left onto Bixby Hill Road to find the Essex Elementary School parking lot. The trailhead is on the northern end of the parking lot.
Trowbridge Crossing.features: Short wetland trail connecting Essex Elementary and nearby neighborhoods.

Student Conservation Association Trails.name: Student Conservation Association Trails
Student Conservation Association Trails.trailhead:
The Trailhead is located off River Road just north of the SCA building nearest the river.
Lebanon to Charlestown
Starting from 5 Airport Rd, West Lebanon, NH 03784-1658
Arriving at 689 River Rd, Charlestown, NH 3603-4171
Distance 27.9 miles Approximate
Travel Time: 37 mins
Directions

Start at 5 AIRPORT RD, WEST LEBANON - go < 0.1 mi
Turn Right on S MAIN ST - go 0.2 mi
Turn Left onto I-89 NORTH - go 1.2 mi
Take the I-91 SOUTH exit toward BRATTLEBORO - go 18.6 mi.
Take exit #8/VT-131 toward WINDSOR/ASCUTNEY - go 0.2 mi
Turn Left on VT ROUTE 131[VT-131] - go 0.5 mi
Bear Right on VT-103 - go 0.4 mi
VT-103 becomes CENTRAL RD[RT-103] - go 0.6 mi
Turn Right on RT-12A - go 6.2 mi
Arrive at 689 RIVER RD, CHARLESTOWN, on the Right
Student Conservation Association Trails.features: Narrow path leads down a set of rock steps towards the Connecticut River under forested cover and continues north along the river to an open field.  The trail loops back through field and woodlands to the SCA office facilities.

Swanton Recreation Path.name: Swanton Recreation Path
Swanton Recreation Path.trailhead: Take I-89 to Exit 21.  Follow Route 78W one mile through Swanton  village.  Immediately after crossing the bridge, take a left on to South  River Street.  Park at the restored train station on your right.
Swanton Recreation Path.features: Swanton History Museum (rehabilitated RR station), 453' three-span bridge, historic signs

Quechee Green Trail.name: Quechee Green Trail
Quechee Green Trail.trailhead: From Exit 1, I-89, head west for approximately 3.8 miles. Turn right onto Waterman Hill Rd., continue for 0.2 mi. to Quechee Main St., turn left and proceed for 0.2 mi. Turn left onto Village Green. Continue 300' to intersection (Trailhead is 200' to your right). Turn left for parking.
Quechee Green Trail.features: Flat loop around Quechee Green Park with views of Ottauquechee River

Notch Road- Class 4 Section.name: Notch Road- Class 4 Section
Notch Road- Class 4 Section.trailhead: Exit 8 off I-89, proceed north on Center Road then turn left onto Notch Road. Proceed for 1.64 miles, bear right at T junction and continue another 0.37 miles. At the end of the Class 3 section of the road there is a sign on the left for the Middlesex Notch Wildlife Management Area and parking is available along the side of the road but please don't block access to anyone's driveways or the Class 4 section of  the road that continues from this point.
Notch Road- Class 4 Section.features: Rocky cliffs on the east side of the road, beaver pond beyond the Middlesex/Waterbury town line in Waterbury.

Montpelier - Wells River Rail Trail (Gro.name: Montpelier - Wells River Rail Trail (Groton - Marshfield)
Montpelier - Wells River Rail Trail (Gro.trailhead: Numerous trailheads and parking areas along the trail, see map.
Montpelier - Wells River Rail Trail (Gro.features: Trail made from former railbed connects Groton State Forest with village centers of Marshfield, Groton, and South Ryegate.

Mt. Ascutney State Park.name: Mt. Ascutney State Park
Mt. Ascutney State Park.trailhead: To Mt. Ascutney State Park Gate: From I-91 (Exit 8): Go .2 mi. E on Rt 131 to stop light, turn left on Rt. 5 for 1.2 mi., then bear left on Rt. 44A for 1 mi.
Mt. Ascutney State Park.features:
Many great vistas await you from the top of the Mt. Ascutney lookout tower and from view points located along four base to summit trails.
For shorter hikes, drive up the Mountain Road to the upper parking area where a half mile hike will take you to the summit.

Russell Family Trails.name: Russell Family Trails
Russell Family Trails.trailhead: From the Hinesburg Town Hall, travel south on Route 116 for .3 miles. Then turn left onto Lyman Meadows Road. Follow Lyman Meadows Road for 100 yards. Turn left onto Lyman Park Road.  Follow Lyman Park Road for 100 yards into the gravel parking area (facing the back of the Catholic Church).  To access trails, cross Lyman Park fields in a northeasterly direction to the trailhead located just beyond the baseball diamond.
Russell Family Trails.features: Pleasant woods and fields trails on a working farm.  Features rolling landscape offering vistas of Hinesburg Village and beyond.

Mascoma Valley Regional High School Trai.name: Mascoma Valley Regional High School Trails
Mascoma Valley Regional High School Trai.trailhead:
I-89 to exit 17 in New Hampshire
Route 4 East to Canaan, NH
Left turn onto 27 Royal Road, Canaan, NH
Park behind the high school and access two trailheads from the parking lot
Mascoma Valley Regional High School Trai.features:
Student maintained trails wander around the ~90 acres of school property.
Riverwalk Trail follows the Mascoma River out to NH Fish and Game managed land.
Traverse Trail wanders through the woods along the perimeter of the middle school fields and parking lot.
The Cross Country Trail loops out into the woods and back to its own start, or a spur trail can be followed into the NH fish and Game managed land.
The New Trail is a work in progress. Follow bright pink flagging tape to extend the trail system another .3 miles and rejoin the high school football field after passing a vernal pool.

Bikepaths in Burlington.name: Bikepaths in Burlington
Bikepaths in Burlington.features: Municipal connections in the City of Burlington

Indian Brook Park.name: Indian Brook Park
Indian Brook Park.trailhead: Follow Route 15 from either Essex Junction (5-corners) or Jericho toward the Essex Outlet Stores at Lang Farm. Turn north on Old Stage Road. Take your second left at the Alliance church onto Indian Brook Road. Follow this dirt road until the end, where you enter the park. For riding the loop you can start from either the lower parking lot (take your first left inside the park) or the upper boat launch lot (first right inside the park).
Indian Brook Park.features: Multi-use path shared by hikers, horseback riders, dog-walkers and mountain bikers alike.

Helen Woodruff Smith Bird Sanctuary.name: Helen Woodruff Smith Bird Sanctuary
Helen Woodruff Smith Bird Sanctuary.trailhead: From Route 120 at flashing light in Meriden, NH, turn onto Main Street heading past Kimball Union Academy. Park at the top of the hill to you right in front of the stone built Meriden Congregational Church. Walk west on grass path next to the Parish house until reaching the Bird Sanctuary entrance.
Helen Woodruff Smith Bird Sanctuary.features:
Several paths wind through this 32 acre bird sanctuary amongst tall towering pines which provide much of the forest cover.
The terrain is very gentle with the exception of a few steeper slopes located near the back section of this property.
