Shelburne Farms.name: Shelburne Farms
Shelburne Farms.trailhead: Follow Route 7 South to the first traffic light in the center of Shelburne. Turn right at this light onto Harbor Road. Follow to the first stop sign and turn left into Shelburne Farms.
Shelburne Farms.features: Explore woodlands, meadows & vistas on 8 miles of trails.

Mill Brook Path.name: Mill Brook Path
Mill Brook Path.trailhead: Trail access is located across from the Fayston School on German Flats Road, off of Route 17.
Mill Brook Path.features: The 3.5 mile steep hiking trail is a favorite for mountain bikers and skiers.

Meadow Loop Trail.name: Meadow Loop Trail
Meadow Loop Trail.trailhead: From US Route 7 in Pittsford travel south on Arch street (Kamuda's Country Store is at the junction of Rte 7 and Arch Street).  The trail head is on the south side of Arch Street, east of the fire station. Parking is off Arch Street west of the fire station lot where the sign says "Trail Parking".
Meadow Loop Trail.features: Walk through fields, woods and along Sugar Hollow Brook.  Enjoy spectacular views.

Gillespie / Copp-Welch Trails.name: Gillespie / Copp-Welch Trails
Gillespie / Copp-Welch Trails.trailhead:
There are three ways to access the trails:

Upper Gilman Road Access:
From Hinesburg Town Hall, go south on Route 116 for 1.5 miles. Turn right onto Gilman Rd for 1.3 miles. You can park in the field on the right, near the road. An improved parking area is planned for this access in the future.
Lower Gilman Road Access:
From Hinesburg Town Hall, go south on Route 116 for 3.4 miles. Turn Right onto Hines Rd. The road forks in 0.6 miles; bear left and continue for 0.2 miles; you will see a driveway on your right. There is no parking area but you can park along Gilman Road in such a way as to not obstruct traffic. Use the driveway on foot to access the trailhead. The driveway is a public right-of-way to these trails.
Lewis Creek Road Access:
From Hinesburg Town Hall, go south on Route 116 for 0.1 miles. Bear right onto Silver Street for 2.8 miles. Turn Left onto Lewis Creek Road. Trail access is a small break in the woods on the left in about 0.4 miles. There is no parking area. In the winter there is no room at this trailhead. Other times you can pull one car into the trailhead area and perhaps park others along Lewis Creek Road. Do not obstruct normal traffic flow. Do not park in front of the mowed lawn of the house near the Lewis Creek Road access.
Gillespie / Copp-Welch Trails.features: Several miles of foot trails located a few miles southeast of Hinesburg village center. You'll find both forest and field trails for hiking, skiing, snowshoeing, and horseback riding on.

West Rutland Marsh.name: West Rutland Marsh
West Rutland Marsh.trailhead: From Route 4, take exit 6 (Proctor/W. Rutland) then take Route 4A west into West Rutland.  At the flashing red light at the intersection of US Business Route 4 (Main Street) and Marble Street at the town hall in West Rutland go north for 1.4 miles on Marble Street.  Look for a small parking area on the left with a sign "West Rutland Marsh Boardwalk".
West Rutland Marsh.features: Birder's World magazine listed the West Rutland Marsh in its October 2008 edition as one of the birding hotspots that can be found in the United States.   There is a long boardwalk that extends into the heart of the marsh and an interpretive trail.  The Audubon Society hosts monthly bird monitoring walks. To date over 900 participants have tallied 136 species from American bittern to northern shrike. To check for the next scheduled walk check www.rutlandcountyaudubon.org.

Intervale Trail.name: Intervale Trail
Intervale Trail.trailhead:
From Burlington, take North Winooski Avenue north to Riverside Avenue. At traffic light, turn left onto Intervale Road. Continue on 0.5 mile, crossing the train tracks and passing Gardener's Supply. You'll find a parking area on the right just after the road turns to dirt.
The trail may also be accessed from the north, near Ethan Allen Homestead. Take the Rt. 127 ramp to Ethan Allen Homestead and find a small parking lot just to the right. The trail is to the right of the parking lot.
Intervale Trail.features: Organic farms and views of the Winooski River

Marshall Avenue Bike Path.name: Marshall Avenue Bike Path
Marshall Avenue Bike Path.features: Urban trail with access to shopping. Nice setback from busy road.

River Trail.name: River Trail
River Trail.features: Riverside trail that passes through tall pines along the Connecticut River and follows Mink Brook back to S. Main St.

Cross Rivendell Trail.name: Cross Rivendell Trail
Cross Rivendell Trail.trailhead: There are a number of public trailheads along the 36 mile trail. Please consult the Cross Rivendell Trail website (www.crossrivendelltrail.org) as well as the Cross RIvendell Trail waterproof map and  Cross Rivendell Trail Guidebook.
Cross Rivendell Trail.features: A 36-mile community trail from Mount Cube (Orford, NH) to Flagpole Hill (Vershire, VT) connecting the 4 towns of of the Rivendell Interstate School District (Orford, NH, Fairlee, West Fairlee, and Vershire, VT).

VT LAMB Ride.name: VT LAMB Ride
VT LAMB Ride.features: The classic VT four gap ride. This climber's route is one of the Green Mountains' most challenging test pieces.

Underhill State Park.name: Underhill State Park
Underhill State Park.trailhead: From I-89 Northbound: Take exit 11 and turn right at W Main St/ US Rt 2. Bear right to River Rd/ VT Route 117. In about 260', turn right onto Governor Peck Highway and follow to end. Turn left onto Browns Trace Road and follow to end (about 5.3 miles). Turn right onto Route 15 and follow for half a mile. Turn right onto River Road. Continue onto Pleasant Valley Rd (2.7 miles). Turn right onto Mountain Road and follow for 2.7 miles to end.
Underhill State Park.features: Underhill State Park features trails the lead up to the Long Trail which then proceeds to the top of Mt. Mansfield, the Chin.

New Boston Trail.name: New Boston Trail
New Boston Trail.trailhead: From Rutland, follow Route 7 north, past a stoplight outside of town. Bear right onto East Pittsford Road, which turns into Chittenden Road at 3.3 miles.  Continue for 2.7 miles on Chittenden Road to a three-way junction.  Bear left at this junction and then go straight, to the right of the Civil War Monument, onto  Mountain Top Road.  Follow it for 1.8 miles and go straight past Mountain Top Inn onto a dirt road.  This road turns into Forest Road 99 at 0.6 miles.  FR 99 is passable only by high clearance vehicles.  Trailhead parking is at 1.3 miles on the left at the FR 99 road gate.
New Boston Trail.features: A nice hike in Chittenden to the David Logan Shelter and access to the Long Trail.

Cross Town Trail.name: Cross Town Trail
Cross Town Trail.features: The Cross Town Trail runs from the highest point on Old City Falls Road to the Sharon town line with a length of over 10 miles. Follow the old Copperas Road leading from the south end  to connect to the Norwich Gile Mountain trails and beyond.

Means Woods.name: Means Woods
Means Woods.trailhead: For access to Means Woods, use the Battell/Means Woods Parking area, but begin hiking 100 yards east of the parking area on the north side of Seminary St. Extension.

Blueberry Hill Ski Center.name: Blueberry Hill Ski Center
Blueberry Hill Ski Center.trailhead: Partly dirt and paved, Goshen Ripton Road, Addison County, Vermont
Blueberry Hill Ski Center.features: 70 km of cross country ski trails and snowshoe trails, within the 22,000 acres of protected lands of the Moosalamoo National Recreation Area.

Cadwell Trail.name: Cadwell Trail
Cadwell Trail.trailhead: There are two trailheads for this trail.  One trailhead is at a farm road approximately 0.6 miles south on Elm Street from the interseciton with US Route 7; the other access is about 1 mile from US Route 7 south on Elm Street at the Cooley Covered Bridge.
Cadwell Trail.features: Walking is easy with two short uphill climbs.  The trail courses through fields and meadows, meandering along Otter Creek, Furnace Brook and a lagoon.

Oak View Hill Trail.name: Oak View Hill Trail
Oak View Hill Trail.trailhead:
From Route 2: At the 4-way stop in Williston Village Center, go south on Oak Hill Road.  The trailhead parking area is on the west (right) side of Oak Hill Road, a few miles from the 4-way stop.
From 1-89: Take Williston exit 12. Go west towards Hinesburg at St. George Rd/VT-2A; go .8 miles to Creamery Road. Turn left at Creamery Rd; go 2 miles. Take a slight right at Oak Hill Rd; go almost 1.5 mi to small parking area on right.
Oak View Hill Trail.features: Beautiful short loop through farm fields and sugar maples. Trail rises slowly from fields into the woods.  It comes back around past a small pond and wooded knoll with a fantastic view across the valley, including Camel's Hump and Mt. Mansfield.

Bikepaths in Colchester.name: Bikepaths in Colchester
Bikepaths in Colchester.trailhead: Various starting points around the town.
Bikepaths in Colchester.features: Municipal connections in the town of Colchester

Upper Valley Loop Trail.name: Upper Valley Loop Trail
Upper Valley Loop Trail.trailhead:
Use Trail Finder map to identify various options to reach the LOOP.
Consider the use of Public Transit bike carriers or Park and Ride facilities (Huntley Meadow in Norwich or Route 5 Park and Ride by Bugbee Street in Hartford) to get you near or on the LOOP with your bike.
Upper Valley Loop Trail.features:
On-road bicycle route connecting Norwich, Hartford, Lebanon and Hanover.
This LOOP forms the central hub of the Upper Valley Trail Network.

South Esker Trail.name: South Esker Trail
South Esker Trail.trailhead:
From the Wheelock St./Main St. intersection in Hanover,NH:
Head south onto Main St. for 1.3 miles, passing by Maple St., and across Mink Brook  to the Pine Knoll Cemetery. Turn right into the cemetery entrance and continue east (staying left at the fork) until you arrive at the Water Reclamation Facility (Wastewater Treatment facility) gate. Park to your right just outside the gate. Walk back along the access road to the west until you see the blue and white signs marking the South Esker Natural Area. Turn right to access the trail.
Another entrance to trail also located at the end of Spencer Road (south of Pine Knoll Cemetery access).
South Esker Trail.features: Trails loop to bluffs above the Connecticut River.

Johnnie Brook Road Trail.name: Johnnie Brook Road Trail
Johnnie Brook Road Trail.trailhead:
This trail is a link in the Cross Vermont Trail from Richmond to Williston and does not have distinct endpoints where you could park a car. (See note on parking below.) At the northwest, it links with the town-maintained (unpaved) part of Johnnie Brook Road - a sharp turn south beside the Winooski River just west of where Route 2 crosses the Winooski River. After 1.2 miles, Johnnie Brook Rd turns into a driveway. Where the driveway takes a sharp right ('trailhead'), continue straight, downhill, on the old town road. At the south-east the Trail starts on Huntington Road about 0.6 miles west of the Richmond Round Church ('trailhead').

To remain on the Cross Vermont Trail, going east, stay on Huntington Road, to the Richmond Round Church and then take Cochran Road towards Duxbury. To go west, take a left on Route 2 at the end of Johnnie Brook Road, towards Williston, then right on Governor Chittenden Road at the foot of French's Hill.
No parking available at trailheads. Both ends of the actual trail are actively used by farm and residential traffic, and would be blocked by parked cars. Please do not park at these points. Doing so would obstruct users of the Class 4 town road.
There is parking at the Volunteer Green in Richmond (just north of the Winooski River Bridge). Also, on the maintained section of Johnnie Brook Road there are some pull-outs used for fishing, etc. Richmond 'Park-and-Ride' is about a half mile from the Route 2 - Johnnie Brook Road intersection.
Johnnie Brook Road Trail.features: A link in the Cross Vermont Trail with views of the Winooski River Valley, a bridge over Johnnie Brook, and active farmland.

Great Meadow Trail.name: Great Meadow Trail
Great Meadow Trail.trailhead: Starting in the center of Charlestown, head south on Route 12 until you reach the southern end of town, just past the Charlestown Middle School. Take a right onto "Lower Landing Road" and follow it to the end. Plenty of parking. If looking at the river, the trail starts through a few trees to the left. Follow the mowed section past the water Treatment Plant.
Great Meadow Trail.features: Beautiful trail that follows the Connecticut River. Great for familes/children, flat/easy trail.

North Hero State Park.name: North Hero State Park
North Hero State Park.trailhead: Take US Route 2 to North Hero.  From the village, go north on US Route 2 3.5miles and then turn right on Lakeview Drive.  Follow Lakeview Drive 3.5 miles until you get to the park entrance.
North Hero State Park.features: Easy scenic wooded trails around the lakeshore state park.

Alburgh Dunes State Park.name: Alburgh Dunes State Park
Alburgh Dunes State Park.trailhead: From US Route 2 in Alburg, VT, turn west on to Rt 129 and go 1.1 miles. Turn left on to Route 129 Extension and go 0.1 miles.  Take a slight left on to Coon Point Road and follow it to the parking area.
Alburgh Dunes State Park.features: A scenic State Park with swimming and a half-mile bike/pedestrian beach road following the Lake Champlain shoreline.

Blue Mountain Nature Trail.name: Blue Mountain Nature Trail
Blue Mountain Nature Trail.trailhead: Blue Mt Union School, Rte 302, Village of Wells River, just east of I-91 exit 17. Alternate: Boltonville trailhead, on Rte 302, in Newbury, just east of Boltonville Rd.
Blue Mountain Nature Trail.features: Cross country running and skiing and nature trail along Wells River on Blue Mountain Union School property.

Montshire Museum Trails.name: Montshire Museum Trails
Montshire Museum Trails.trailhead: The Montshire is located off I-91, at exit 13 (watch for the Museum of Science interstate sign) in Norwich, VT; five miles north of White River Junction, VT, and directly across the Connecticut River from Hanover, NH, and Dartmouth College.
Montshire Museum Trails.features: The Montshire Museum includes 110 acres of woodland and nature trails with intriguing exhibits and vistas of the Connecticut River.

Trail Around Middlebury (TAM).name: Trail Around Middlebury (TAM)
Trail Around Middlebury (TAM).trailhead: Numerous trail heads located around Middlebury.
Trail Around Middlebury (TAM).features: The TAM (Trail Around Middlebury) utilizes existing parks, a ski area, and many private land owners who've allowed access to this town treasure.

Colchester Pond.name: Colchester Pond
Colchester Pond.trailhead: From Route 2 & 7 in Colchester, take 2A east to Colchester Village. Turn left onto East Road. Turn right onto Depot Road. Follow Depot Road, staying left until you reach the pond. The parking area is at the end of the road. NOTE: Please do not park along the road.
Colchester Pond.features: Gorgeous pond nestled amongst rolling hills offers hiking, paddling and birding.

Millstone Hill Touring and Recreation Ce.name: Millstone Hill Touring and Recreation Center
Millstone Hill Touring and Recreation Ce.trailhead: The Millstone Hill Touring Center is located in Websterville on Church Hill Rd., inside the Millstone HIll General Store. Look for a yellow building across from the Post Office.
Millstone Hill Touring and Recreation Ce.features: Outstanding views, scenic quarries, large grout (granite) piles, historic features.

Pease Mountain.name: Pease Mountain
Pease Mountain.trailhead:
From Route 7 in Charlotte heading south, turn left at Church Hill Rd. After 0.7 mile, turn right at the stop sign onto Hinesburg Road. The school is on the right after about 0.3 mile.
The trailhead is located on top of a hill in the southwest corner behind the athletic fields at Charlotte Central School. Park between the metal maintenance shed and the school, walk across the athletic fields and up the hill to a large informational sign marks the trailhead.
Pease Mountain.features: There are many options on the length of your hike on Pease Mountain depending on the ability of those in your group and the amount of time that you have.

Hazen Trail.name: Hazen Trail
Hazen Trail.trailhead:
From Wilder:
Trail access is immediately off US Rte 5 between I-91 exits 12  (Wilder) and 13 (Norwich). The dirt access road is 0.2 mile south of the  I-91 overpass, just north of the village of Wilder and 0.5 mile south  of the Dothan Brook School. A green post with 2393 marks the access.  Park along this access road, but do not block the driveway gate.
A kiosk to the right of the parking area provides information about  the Maanawaka Conservation Area where the Hazen Trail begins. From the  kiosk, the trail rises up into the woods and, in about 100 yards, meets  the junction of the Backwater and Hazen Trails.
The Backwater Trail provides a short walk down along an inlet from  the Connecticut River. Near the beginning of the trail, you can see  remains of an old dam just off trail.
From Montshire Road:
The Montshire Road is the first left going uphill from the Ledyard  Bridge between Hanover and Norwich. It is immediately east of the  northbound exit ramp from I-91, exit 13.
Park off the edge of the Montshire Road and walk down the Museum  driveway a short distance to the crosswalk, where the Blood Brook  connector trail begins on the right. Follow the connector traill  (red/orange blazes) a short distance up into the woods to meet the Ridge  Trail (blue blazes). Take the right fork of the Ridge Trail—away from  the Museum. The Hazen Trail (red blazes) branches off to the right in  about 0.6 mile. (See Montshire Museum Trails for more information about  the Ridge Trail)
Hazen Trail.features: This walk is a rolling dirt trail that passes through forest and farmland above the Connecticut River, connecting Hartford just north of Wilder and Norwich. It can be started at either end, but there is limited access from the Norwich (north) end of the trail (see trailhead information). The Hazen Trail was conserved by the Upper Valley Land Trust and is well maintained. The Hartford end begins at Dothan Brook off of Route 5. There is also another good out and back trail, the Backwater Trail, which can be added for more distance (see route extension).

Old Jericho Road Trail.name: Old Jericho Road Trail
Old Jericho Road Trail.trailhead: From Richmond, take Jericho Road north. Pass under I-89, and turn left on Southview Dr. After crossing a small brook, park in a lot to the left. Trail begins on the other side of the road.
Old Jericho Road Trail.features: Deep ravine, beautiful rocky brook, stands of hemlock, beech, and maple.

Reservoir Lot Trails.name: Reservoir Lot Trails
Reservoir Lot Trails.trailhead: Follow North Hemlock Road to trailhead on right, down behind an open white gate, right after the intersection with Blueberry Hill Road and before the intersection with the Burroughs Road.
Reservoir Lot Trails.features: Three trails, two connected loops and a side spur. Trail has streamside walks and wooded areas.

Enfield Wildlife Management Area - Lower.name: Enfield Wildlife Management Area - Lower Shaker Village Tract
Enfield Wildlife Management Area - Lower.features:
This network of wood roads and trails provide a variety of recreational routes on Shaker Mountain.
Primary landuse in this area is for Wildlife Management.  Hunting is a primary recreational activity including pheasant and deer hunting in the fall and turkey hunting in the spring.  No wheeled vehicles on bare ground are allowed.

Macrae Farm Park.name: Macrae Farm Park
Macrae Farm Park.trailhead: From Burlington, take Rt 127 North to Colchester. Turn right at the intersection of 127/Macrae Road/Porter's Pt Road. Follow Macrae Road to the end of the road which will eventually turn to dirt, cross over the small bridge, and park in the designated parking area. The meadow and river trails start here and the Hilltop Trail starts back across the bridge and to the right.
Macrae Farm Park.features: River view, meadow loops, and the hilltop trail with views of Mount Mansfield and Camel's Hump.

Mount Philo State Park.name: Mount Philo State Park
Mount Philo State Park.trailhead: From Burlington, take Spear Street South. Turn right to go west on Irish Spring Hill Road. Turn left to go south onto Mt. Philo Road. Continue straight. The Mt. Philo State Park parking lot will be on your left.
Mount Philo State Park.features: Short hike offering views of Charlotte, Lake Champlain, and the Adirondack mountains of New York.

Greensboro Ridge - Troop 45 Trail.name: Greensboro Ridge - Troop 45 Trail
Greensboro Ridge - Troop 45 Trail.trailhead: From Greensboro Road turn onto Velvet Rock Drive.  The trailhead and parking is at the end of Velvet Rocks Drive.
Greensboro Ridge - Troop 45 Trail.features: Oli's Eagle trail has moderate terrain and moderate incline.  Sections of the trail require walking over rocks and boulders, so proper footwear to prevent slipping is recommended.

King Arthur Trail.name: King Arthur Trail
King Arthur Trail.trailhead:
From I-91N take Exit 13. From traffic lights at end of off ramp, turn left onto Main St., proceed under I-91 to the Route 5 intersection. Turn left onto Route 5 S.
From I-91S take Exit 13 to traffic lights at end of off ramp. Continue straight ahead onto Route 5 S.
Travel 0.7 miles, turn left into the Dresden Athletic Fields driveway (Colton Center driveway), stay right on driveway, continuing to the trailhead kiosk. Park in gravel parking area just past kiosk.
Note: Alternate trail access points and parking at King Arthur Flour Co. are currently closed during their construction project to ensure safety (expected project timeframe is June 2011 - spring 2012). Direct access from Mill Road through to the Dresden Athletic Fields will not be available.
King Arthur Trail.features: 6' wide forested trail offering off road access from Mill Road to the Dresden Athletic Fields.

Path of Life Garden Trail.name: Path of Life Garden Trail
Path of Life Garden Trail.trailhead: The garden is located at 36 Park Rd. in Windsor, Vermont. Take I-91 to  Exit 9 then go South on Rt. 5 for 1 mile. Or you can call (802) 674-9933 and we  will talk you in!
Path of Life Garden Trail.features:
The Path of Life is a public sculpture garden in Windsor, Vermont that tells the story of the great circle of life.
Visitors follow a winding path through a field that leads them to 18 different "rooms".
It's a really great destination for family fun.

Norwich Nature Area Trails.name: Norwich Nature Area Trails
Norwich Nature Area Trails.trailhead: From the center of Norwich, take Main St. toward I-91 and turn left at the east end of the green, in front of the Marion Cross School where a historic sign marks the Theta Chi Fraternity. Follow the driveway toward the Marion Cross School and turn into the 1st parking lot on the right. The trailhead is at the end of the lot. Available at the Marion Cross School and is free. Note that the driveway is closed to all traffic during the bus times noted on the driveway sign. (7:30 - 8:00 A.M.; 2:50 - 3:20 P.M.)
Norwich Nature Area Trails.features: These relatively short trails are recommended for walking, snowshoeing, and cross country skiing. Dogs under control are allowed, but owners are requested to clean up after their pets. Wheeled vehicles are prohibited. When the nearby school is not in session, parking is generally plentiful. During school hours, parking can be found in the village area of Norwich.

George R. Clapp Nature Trail.name: George R. Clapp Nature Trail
George R. Clapp Nature Trail.trailhead: Take Route 15 east through Essex. Route 15 turns right, go straight to join Route 128. The trailhead is just across from the Elementary School, on the right.
George R. Clapp Nature Trail.features: Children-oriented trail with a small pond.

Schultz Trail.name: Schultz Trail
Schultz Trail.trailhead:
Year-round: From Westford Village, head northeast on the Cambridge Road then turn right onto Old Number 11 Road. Continue for 2 miles, and keep right past Kilburn Lane. The trailhead is at the cul-de-sac at the end of Old Number 11 Road. Please be courteous of the property owner by not blocking access to the house, garage, or the trail. The trail is marked with a "Public Trail" sign.
Non-winter access: From Westford village, take Route 128 South to Osgood Hill Road. Proceed 1.5 mile and turn left onto Machia Hill Road. After 0.7 mile, look for "Public Trail" sign.

LaPlatte River Marsh Natural Area.name: LaPlatte River Marsh Natural Area
LaPlatte River Marsh Natural Area.trailhead: From Shelburne Road/Route 7, turn west onto Bay Road. The trailhead is less than a mile down the road on the left, just across from the Shelburne Bay fishing access parking lot.
LaPlatte River Marsh Natural Area.features: Tranquil wildlife observation along this marsh trail.

Gilbrook Natural Area.name: Gilbrook Natural Area
Gilbrook Natural Area.trailhead: From Burlington, cross the Winooski bridge. Take the roundabout to Route 15 (East Allen Street). Take a left onto Dion Street, then a right turn onto Lafountain Street. Go under the I-89 overpass, then take the next left onto Gilbrook Road. The trailhead is at the end of the road, look for the signs.
Gilbrook Natural Area.features: Interpretive trail offers up close view of ecology.

Downer State Forest.name: Downer State Forest
Downer State Forest.trailhead:
From Main St. in Norwich, VT., follow Beaver Meadow Rd. 8.9 miles to Downer Rd. in Sharon, VT. Turn right and continue 1.6 miles to Camp Downer. Park on left pullout located before camp entrance being careful not to block gates.
From Route 132, Sharon, VT., follow Beaver Meadow Rd. south for .2 miles to Downer Rd. Turn left and continue for 1.6 miles to Camp Downer. Park on left pullout located before camp entrance being careful not to block gates.
Additional parking is available at several wide turnouts along the state forest highway network.
Parking for southern end of State Forest Highway is available at a wide turnout located along State Forest Highway approx. 0.25 miles north of intersection with Beaver meadow Road.
State Forest Highway is gated on both ends. Gates are closed during spring mud season to protect the road from damage but gates are usually opened by mid-May. Bikes and horses are not allowed on the road when the gates are closed.
Downer State Forest.features: Gravel road loop and connector linking northern and southern State Forest Parcels.

Mad River Westside Greenway.name: Mad River Westside Greenway
Mad River Westside Greenway.trailhead: Access the trail from Meadow Road, off Route 100.
Mad River Westside Greenway.features: This is the easiest and most popular section of the Path with the river close by on one side, and farm fields on the other.

Mink Brook Preserve.name: Mink Brook Preserve
Mink Brook Preserve.trailhead: From Route 10 in Hanover, turn onto Brook Road.  Parking is available by the trailhead on Brook Road.
Mink Brook Preserve.features: The property offers a variety of walking terrains.  The easy terrain of Quinn Trail is accessible to both strollers and wheelchairs and links up with the trails in the Tanzi Tract, a preserve of the Town of Hanover.   On the south side of Mink Brook wooded hiking trails link up with trails to preserved land in Lebanon.

Covered Bridges.name: Covered Bridges
Covered Bridges.trailhead: Shelburne Village Green across from Shelburne Country Store, just off Route 7.
Covered Bridges.features: Travel the country dirt roads of Chittenden County over covered bridges with two museums en route.

Victor Hewes Memorial Park - Nature Trai.name: Victor Hewes Memorial Park - Nature Trail
Victor Hewes Memorial Park - Nature Trai.trailhead: From Route 12A in Plainfield NH, head north towards West Lebanon. After passing the Plainfield Cemetery, turn right onto Stage Road. Pass by the house on the corner to reach a open field. A small parking area is located on the far end of the field next to Stage Road.
Victor Hewes Memorial Park - Nature Trai.features: A quaint gently sloping trail that follows the steep upper bank of Blow-Me-Down Brook.

North of the Big Hills.name: North of the Big Hills
North of the Big Hills.trailhead: Richmond Town Park, just South of Route 2 in Richmond.
North of the Big Hills.features: A hilly route through the heart of Richmond, Huntington, and Hinesburg, each with its own unique village center.

Leicester Hollow/Chandler Ridge Loop.name: Leicester Hollow/Chandler Ridge Loop
Leicester Hollow/Chandler Ridge Loop.trailhead: The Minnie Baker trail head is in the Town of Leicester off Route 53.
Leicester Hollow/Chandler Ridge Loop.features: A moderate all-day hike with turnaround point at Silver Lake. Views  to east and west along Chandler Ridge.

Awasiwi Trail.name: Awasiwi Trail
Awasiwi Trail.trailhead: Behind S. Burlington High School on Dorset Street; Hinesburg Road (Rt 116); and Hawthorne Circle
Awasiwi Trail.features: Suburban trail connecting several neighborhoods along Potash Brook. Passes by seasonal snowboard training park near S. Burlington High School athletic fields.

Hubbard Hill State Forest Trail.name: Hubbard Hill State Forest Trail
Hubbard Hill State Forest Trail.trailhead: Follow North Hemlock Road to Burroughs Road, the trailhead is .5 miles is on the left. Look for "Hubbard State Forest" sign at parking entrance.

Charlotte Town Link.name: Charlotte Town Link
Charlotte Town Link.trailhead: To  reach the Co-housing section of the Link Trail, from the Charlotte west  village center, drive south on Greenbush Rd for 1.3 miles. Turn East  onto Common Way. In about 0.3 mile there is a sign directing you to a  parking area on the left. Park your car, then continue walking east on  Common Way for a few minutes. On the right you will see the entrance for  the trail marked by a Charlotte Link Trail sign.

Thetford Academy Cross Country Trail.name: Thetford Academy Cross Country Trail
Thetford Academy Cross Country Trail.trailhead: From I-91 take exit 14 and head west on Rte 113 to the top of Thetford Hill. Turn left on Academy Rd. and proceed to the Thetford Academy on your right. Use the parking lot adjacent to the school. The trailhead is located behind the school buildings, at the back of the athletic fields.
Thetford Academy Cross Country Trail.features: A multi-season trail in Thetford designed by John Morton, a local resident and Olympic athlete.

Chittenden Brook.name: Chittenden Brook
Chittenden Brook.trailhead: From the intersection of US Route 7 and VT Route 73 East in Brandon village, go east on Route 73 for 12.1 miles through Goshen and over Brandon Gap to a right turn onto Green Mountain National Forest Road 45.  Go for 0.6 miles on Forest Road 45 to a trailhead and small parking area on the right.  Park in the parking area.  Start your hike on the trail that leaves the road at the south end of the parking area.  (Note:  in winter Forest Road 45 may be closed to cars by snow.  You can park in a parking area at the intersection of Route 73 and Forest Road 45 and extend the round trip hiking distance to 4.6 miles and the elevation gain is 560 feet.)
Chittenden Brook.features: An old wood road that parallels  Chittenden Brook.

Burnt Hill Trail.name: Burnt Hill Trail
Burnt Hill Trail.trailhead: The trail head is in the Town of Ripton on Forest Road 59.
Burnt Hill Trail.features: 1.5-2 hours one way with access to the Long Trail.

Bill Ballard Trail.name: Bill Ballard Trail
Bill Ballard Trail.trailhead: Three parking areas provide access to the trail off Beaver Meadow Road in Norwich (the first left turn immediately after Dan & Whits and the Norwich Inn): the Norwich Pool (on the left just over 1 mile from the Inn, immediately before Brigham Hill Road); Parcel 5 (1.4 miles from the Pool, and directly across Beaver Meadow Road from Brown Schoolhouse Road), and roadside parking (2.7 miles from the Pool, just before Tucker Hill Road).
Bill Ballard Trail.features: The 4 mile Bill Ballard Trail parallels Charles Brown Brook and Beaver Meadow Road in Norwich and features the "Grand Canyon of Norwich". The mostly level wooded trail includes many ups and downs to cross numerous seasonal creeks that flow to Charles Brown Brook - the most spectacular creek creating the "Grand Canyon" in the upper half of the trail. The trail is limited to foot travel; dogs are permitted.  Bicycles and horses are not allowed.

Bomoseen State Park - Glen Lake Overlook.name: Bomoseen State Park - Glen Lake Overlook
Bomoseen State Park - Glen Lake Overlook.trailhead: From the intersection of US Route 4A and VT Route 30 go west on Route 4A  for 1.3 miles to Creek Road (Hydeville).  Lake Bomoseen Inn is on the  corner.  Turn right onto Creek Road, which becomes West Castleton Road,  for 4.0 miles to the entrance to Bomoseen State Park campground.   Continue around the curve to the left and, in a complicated  intersection, choose the gravel Moscow Road - right hand turn.  Go north  on Moscow Road for 0.8 miles to a sign on the left "Bomoseen State Park  - Glen Lake Block" and a driveway leading to a large, grassy field.   Park in the field.  Start your walk along the roadway leading south from  the southwest corner of the grassy field.
Bomoseen State Park - Glen Lake Overlook.features:
A walk along the shore of Glen Lake; then a short climb to a great view of the lake from above.

This is a short section of the Glen Lake Trail that leads from the boat access area on Glen Lake to Half Moon campground.

Heart of the Islands Bike Tour :: 10-Mil.name: Heart of the Islands Bike Tour :: 10-Mile Route
Heart of the Islands Bike Tour :: 10-Mil.trailhead: The tour starts at Snow Farm Winery in South Hero.
Heart of the Islands Bike Tour :: 10-Mil.features: Bike to the heart of the Champlain Islands on July 9th with Vermont Farm Tours during the fourth annual Open Farm and Studio Weekend.

Mt. Independence State Historic Site.name: Mt. Independence State Historic Site
Mt. Independence State Historic Site.trailhead: To reach the site, take Route 73 west from Orwell and take the first left turn. This is a paved town road that forks; take the right fork. The road will turn to gravel and go parallel to Lake Champlain. Once again the road will fork; take a sharp left hand turn towards a small marina. The parking lot for the historic site is on the left at the top of the hill.
Mt. Independence State Historic Site.features: Six miles of walking and hiking trails that wind past the Revolutionary War era remains of batteries, blockhouses, the general hospital, barracks, and soldier's huts. Site offer vistas of Lake Champlain and the countryside.

Saxon Hill School District Park.name: Saxon Hill School District Park
Saxon Hill School District Park.trailhead:
Park at the end of Saxon Hill Rd. Turn at Saxon Hill Auto off of Rt. 15 and bear right until you reach the gate. This very small parking area is the only spot approved by the Town of Essex to park for access to the Saxon Hill trail network. There is space for 2 or 3 cars without blocking the private driveway, so please carpool or ride your bike to the trailhead! Thanks for your respect of the neighbors.
Trail users are asked not to park on Thompson Drive because access to the trail from there is across private land. Please respect landowner wishes and park at the end of Saxon Hill Road instead.

Hinesburg Town Forest.name: Hinesburg Town Forest
Hinesburg Town Forest.trailhead:
Information boards with a map and updates are located at all three trailheads.
There are three Trail access points with parking as identified on the map:
1. Hayden Hill Road  (East):
From Richmond Round Church,
• Take Huntington Road for 5.4 miles, then make a right onto Texas Hill Road
• Follow Texas Hill Road for 1.7 miles;
• Turn left onto Hayden Hill Road East and follow for 0.5 mile.
• The parking area for the Hinesburg Town Forest is on the left, marked by a large wooden sign for the Eagle’s Trail.
2. Hayden Hill Road: ((West):
From Hinesburg
• South on Route 116 for 2.2 miles;
• Turn left onto North Road;
• Follow North Road for 1.2 miles
• Turn right onto Hayden Hill Road West and follow for 1.5 miles;
• The parking area for the Hinesburg Town Forest is on the right.
3. Ecomomou Road:
From Richmond,
• take Huntington Road to Huntington then make a right onto Texas Hill Road.
• Go about 1/2 mile and make a left onto Texas Hill Circle.
• Follow for about 1 mile and make a left onto Economou Road.
• Follow Economou to the end.
Hinesburg Town Forest.features: The Hinesburg Town Forest  is a unique and wonderfully varied 850 acre piece of land. It is marked by beautiful stands of firs, pines, and birches, as well as a mix of deciduous vegetation.  It is a favorite trail network for beginner, intermediate, and advanced single track mountain biking.

Halls Pond Trail.name: Halls Pond Trail
Halls Pond Trail.trailhead: Follow North Hemlock Road to Borough Road .6 miles to Halls Pond Road and straight onto Peter's Hill Road (class 6, unmaintained, high clearance vehicles needed) .2 miles to trailhead at clearing.
Halls Pond Trail.features: Up a snowmobile trail, around Halls Pond and back.

Balch Hill Natural Area Trails.name: Balch Hill Natural Area Trails
Balch Hill Natural Area Trails.trailhead: Parking is available with access to Hemlock Trail at Hemlock Road. Parking is also available with access to Grasse Road Trail at the intersection of Grasse Road and Trescott Road.
Balch Hill Natural Area Trails.features: Hill top trails, views, multiple trails.

Sleepy Hollow.name: Sleepy Hollow
Sleepy Hollow.trailhead:
From Interstate 89: Take Exit 11 (Richmond).
Take US Route 2 east to town of Richmond.  At traffic light in Richmond go right onto Bridge Street.
Follow Bridge Street through town, after crossing the bridge, the road takes a sharp right and turns into Huntington Road.
Follow Huntington Rd. for about 5 miles.
Turn right onto Sherman Hollow Road (there are also signs for Birds of Vermont Museum and Green Mountain Audubon Nature Center).
Sleepy Hollow is 1.8 miles up Sherman Hollow Road on the left.
From Hinesburg (Rt. 116) Take Mechanicsville Rd. (or CVU road) to Richmond-Hinesburg Rd. (towards Richmond), follow ~ 2.5 miles
Go right on Magee Hill Rd.(this is a dirt road across from Pond Brook Rd.)
Magee Hill road becomes Sherman Hollow Rd. at 1 mile, follow Sherman Hollow 2.5 miles to Sleepy Hollow, which is on the right.
If you miss Magee Hill Rd. You can also turn right onto Swamp Rd. Follow until it ends (1/2 mile) and then take a left onto Sherman Hollow Rd. Follow 2.5 miles and Sleepy Hollow is on your right.
Sleepy Hollow.features: A family owned and operated small business featuring acclaimed nordic skiing (light blue trails on map) and mountain biking (purple trails on map) in a beautiful setting.  Located in the scenic town of Huntington, Vermont, only 30 minutes from Burlington.  Enjoy miles of running, hiking, mountain biking or well-groomed cross-country skiing trails.

Ethan Allen Homestead.name: Ethan Allen Homestead
Ethan Allen Homestead.trailhead: From Rte. 127, take the "North Beaches" exit. The road to the homestead is directly off the exit ramp.
Ethan Allen Homestead.features: Include the Ethan Allen museum, a picnic area, bathrooms, an outhouse, and some handicap accessible trails.

address.road: Ethan Allan Homestead; Ethan Allen Homestead

Canty Trail.name: Canty Trail
Canty Trail.trailhead: From Route 4 in Mendon proceed east to the junction with the Old Turnpike Road.  Turn north onto Old Turnpike Road and continue (~approximately 2.8 miles) to the trailhead at a gated private lane on the north side of the road. Park on shoulder of public road and be mindful of not blocking private lane.
Canty Trail.features: A moderately challenging hike, with several creek crossings.

Warren and Ruth Beeken Rivershore Trail.name: Warren and Ruth Beeken  Rivershore Trail
Warren and Ruth Beeken Rivershore Trail.trailhead:
Take I-89 to the Richmond exit (exit 11). Get on Route 2 going east. Once in Richmond, turn right at the first traffic light onto Bridge Street. From the center of Richmond at the traffic light go down Bridge St. toward the Round Church. Go over the Winooski bridge and just past the Round Church green turn left on Cochran Rd. There are three ways to access the trail from Cochran Rd.
The first is just across the street from a small cemetery (parking for one or two cars on cemetery side or at Volunteer's Green in town.)
The second is in about midway along the trail at the canoe access about 1.5 miles from the Round Church (parking in the canoe access parking lot.)
The third is at Wheeler Lane, 3 miles from the Round Church or 0.25 miles from the bridge in Jonesville. (This starts along the Huntington River and leads down the Winooski and the trail goes West. Parking is across from the Jonesville post office.)
Note that there are also two short sections where the trail runs along Cochran Road, as indicated on the trail map.
Warren and Ruth Beeken Rivershore Trail.features: Spring ephemerals, ostrich ferns, great vistas of the Winooski River Valley. This trail passes through the longest stretch of riparian forest on the Winooski. Currently it is under threat from invasive species.

Alburgh Recreation Trail.name: Alburgh Recreation Trail
Alburgh Recreation Trail.trailhead: Western Trailhead: Park in the Alburgh Industrial Park, located across from the town fire station off Rt 2. You'll see the start of the path ahead of you at the end of the road (don't bear right).
Alburgh Recreation Trail.features: This 3.5 mile trail is a rail trail in Alburgh. It starts in the center of town and heads east to the lake where there is a small beach.

Quechee Gorge Trail.name: Quechee Gorge Trail
Quechee Gorge Trail.trailhead: Travel about 3 miles on Route 4 from exit 1 from I-89 toward Woodstock. Turn right onto Dewey’s Mills Road after a group of restaurants and shops. This is the last road before Route 4 crosses the Ottauquechee River. At the end of this road turn left on Quehcee Main Street toward Quechee, and then take an immediate left into the Dewey’s Mills Pond parking lot just before the Quechee Inn at Marshland Farm. The ditance from Route 4 is approximately 1 mile. A sign reads “Deweys Landing”.  Alternatively, one may park at the Quechee Gorge Visitor Center on Route 4 adjacent to the gorge.
Quechee Gorge Trail.features: Quechee Gorge is part of the 612-acre Quechee Gorge State Park and is managed for multiple recreational uses by the Vermont Department of Forests Parks & Recreation.

Rattlesnake Cliffs and Aunt Jenny Trail.name: Rattlesnake Cliffs and Aunt Jenny Trail
Rattlesnake Cliffs and Aunt Jenny Trail.trailhead: The trail head is in the Town of Salisbury on Route 53.
Rattlesnake Cliffs and Aunt Jenny Trail.features: One-way trip with views of waterfalls, Silver Lake, and Lake Dunmore. Total time: 1.5-2 hours.

Split Rock Trail.name: Split Rock Trail
Split Rock Trail.trailhead: From Route 7 in Pittsford go North on Oxbow Road (across from Mobil Station).  After approximately 1/2 mile go left on Adams Road; travel one mile on Adams road to trailhead and parking area located just off Adams road. Parking available for two vehicles.
Split Rock Trail.features: An easy loop trail that traverses open fields, through woodlands with a pond.

Abbey Pond.name: Abbey Pond
Abbey Pond.trailhead:
From Middlebury, travel south 4.0 miles on Route 7 to where it intersects with Route 125. Travel east on Route 125 for 0.6 miles to the intersection with Route 116. Travel north on Route 116 for 4.4 miles, and look for a sign for the Abbey Pond Trail on the right. Turn right onto a gravel road and follow the right spur to the trailhead parking at 0.3 miles. The land adjacent to the road and parking lot is private property. Please be respectful of the owner.

From Bristol, travel west 1.0 mile on Route 17 & 116. Turn left onto Route 116 at a blinking light, travel 6.9 miles and look for a sign for the Abbey Pond Trail on the left. Turn left onto a gravel road and follow the right spur to the trail head parking at 0.3 miles. The land adjacent to the road and parking lot is private property. Please be respectful of the owner.
Abbey Pond.features: 2-2.5 hours round trip (3.6 miles) trail suitable for all ages with the turnaround point at Abbey Pond.

Mount Peg Park.name: Mount Peg Park
Mount Peg Park.trailhead: From Woodstock town center go west on Route 4 0.2 miles (around traffic circle) and head south on Route 106. Go south on 106 0.1 mile and turn left on Cross St. Go 0.1 mile on Cross St. and turn right on Golf Ave. Go 0.1 mile on Golf Ave, parking lot is on left immediately after dead-end residential street.
Mount Peg Park.features: Trails with a breathtaking scenic view of Ottauquechee River Valley in historic Woodstock.

Shelburne Pond.name: Shelburne Pond
Shelburne Pond.trailhead: From Shelburne Village (Rt 7), take Falls Road south. Turn left to stay on Falls Road, then continue on Irish Hill Road. At the intersection with Dorset Street, continue on Pond Road. Pond Access Road will be on your left. At the end of this road is a large lot with room for boat trailers. Parking is easy and clearly marked.
Shelburne Pond.features: Beautiful little trail in the woods with views of Shelburne Pond. Great for a casual paddle and fishing, too.

Melissa & Trevor Mack Memorial Trail.name: Melissa & Trevor Mack Memorial Trail
Melissa & Trevor Mack Memorial Trail.features: Crushed gravel double track trail with views of the Adirondacks.

Nat Thompson Trail.name: Nat Thompson Trail
Nat Thompson Trail.trailhead: From the intersection of Three Mile Road at Ruddsboro Road in Hanover, travel north for 1.5 miles on Three Mile Road to the Fred Harris Cabin access trail (Trail 26 on 2009 Town of Hanover Trail Map). Parking at trailhead. Head east on trail for 0.5 miles to the Nat Thompson Cabin (former site of Fred Harris cabin) and the Nat Thompson Trail. Continue for 1.1 miles to the Moose Mountain Peak. Alternatively from trailhead parking,  hike along Three Mile Road for .0.25 miles and turn right onto the Old Fred Harris Cabin access trail, continue for 0.75 miles to the Nat Thompson Cabin.
Nat Thompson Trail.features: This trail provides an easy and enjoyable route, suitable for children,  to the Moose Mountain South Peak Summit.

Indian Ridge.name: Indian Ridge
Indian Ridge.trailhead:
Indian Ridge Trail starts at a trailhead located next to the Gile Hill Road just off Medical Center Drive. Turn west off Route 120 opposite Jesse's restaurant, then right into Gile Hill Road to a trailhead parking lot.
Alternatively, when visiting Sachem fields off Route 10, follow Gould Road east to Drake Lane trun right and continue under powerline corridor to reach and follow the Sachem Connector trail for 0.5 miles to reach the Indian Ridge Trail intersection.
Indian Ridge.features: Trail runs south along the wooded spine of Indian Ridge from Gile Hill to Boston Lot and its trail network.  Ledges face Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center to the east and the Connecticut River and Dartmouth's Baker Tower to the west.

Ice Bed Trail.name: Ice Bed Trail
Ice Bed Trail.trailhead: From US 7 in Wallingford, follow VT. 140 east.  Turn south onto Sugar Hill Road (2.3 miles), then turn right onto White Rocks Picnic Road (USFS Road 52) (2.4 miles), and continue to the picnic area and parking (3.0 miles).
Ice Bed Trail.features: This trail leads to spectacular views of the White Rocks Cliff as well as a spot at the base of a rock slide with large boulders and where ice persists throughout the year.

Mud Pond Conservation Area.name: Mud Pond Conservation Area
Mud Pond Conservation Area.trailhead: From Williston Village, head South on Oak Hill Road. After passing over the highway, turn left onto South Road. Continue on South Road for 2 miles and turn right onto Mud Pond Road. A small parking area is available on Mud Pond Road. Please do not park on South Road.
Mud Pond Conservation Area.features: At Mud Pond, you will get a look at natural wildlife habitat. The trails are for non-motorized use only. Mud Pond consists of 158 acres of wetlands and forests owned by the town of Williston.

Heyl Trail.name: Heyl Trail
Heyl Trail.trailhead:
1)  At Exit 13 of I-91, turn towards the village section of Norwich. Upon entering the village, take the first left onto Elm Street; follow for about 1 mile to the end of the road. Go past the AT kiosk and look for the Heyl Trail sign  on your left at the end of the street. Parking near the trailhead is limited to a few vehicles along Elm Street. Parking is also available in Norwich village.
2) At Exit 13 of I-91, turn towards the village section of Norwich. Upon entering the village, take the second left onto Beaver Meadow Road; continue for about a half mile to the second left, turning there onto Bragg Hill Road. Follow Bragg Hill Road for about 3/4 mile to a power line crossing. The trailhead is sign on the left just beyond the powerline crossing.  Park along the road in nearby widened areas.
Heyl Trail.features: This is an off road link between two dirt roads - Elm St. and Bragg Hill Rd..  The trail also connects with Wilder under the power line.  The Elm St. to power line section is roughly parallel to the AT and the 2 trails form a loop returning to Elm St.

Short Trail.name: Short Trail
Short Trail.trailhead: Located at GMC Visitors Center in Waterbury, VT
Short Trail.features: Journey's End Camp, Interpretive signs, and a bench with a view of Worcester Range

Chickering Bog Natural Area Trail.name: Chickering Bog Natural Area Trail
Chickering Bog Natural Area Trail.trailhead: From Montpelier, take Rt. 2E 6.5 miles to E. Montpelier.  Then take Rt. 14N 3.2 miles to N. Montpelier.  From the Riverbend Store continue on Rt. 14 for 1.1 miles and turn left onto Lightening Ridge Rd.  After 1.6 miles you’ll pass George Rd on the right.  Just after the private driveway on the left the trail is marked by a green post labeled “TNC.”   Park along the right hand side of the road, not in the driveway.
Chickering Bog Natural Area Trail.features: Chickering Bog is home to a large variety of fen plants including grass pink, sundew, cotton grass, blue flag iris, sweet gale, pitcher plant, showy lady's slipper and livid sedge.  Frogs, wood ducks, crows, nuthatches, pileated woodpeckers and the tracks of fur-bearing mammals like bears, white-tailed deer and hares have been spotted here.

Hitchcock Trail.name: Hitchcock Trail
Hitchcock Trail.trailhead: From the intersection of Route 7 and VT Route 3 south of Pittsford Village go north on Route 7 for 0.5 miles to Furnace Road.  Turn right onto Furnace Road for 1.4 miles to its interseciton with Hitchcock Road.  At the intersectin leave Furance Road, which turns to the right, and continue straight ahead on Hitchcock Road for 0.7 miles.  Look for a rough Gravel land on teh right with a sign "Pittsford Trails - Chaffee Falls Trail".  Turn onto the land for 100 yards to a parking area.  Park in the parking area.  Start your walk from either side of the parking area.
Hitchcock Trail.features: An easy woodland walk, partly along a crystal-clear brook.

Lamoille River Walk.name: Lamoille River Walk
Lamoille River Walk.trailhead:
CVPS Trailhead: From Route 7 head west on Ritchie Avenue all the way to the CVPS gate (sometimes closed). Beyond the gate go down the switchback road, past the brick building and old foundation. The trailhead is along the tree line, south of the old foundation. Parking is at CVPS's Route 7 Park.
Checkerberry Trailhead: From Route 7 head north on Nancy Drive. At the end of Nancy Drive, take a left onto Checkerberry Square and follow to the end. Park at the very end of the road and walk north toward the trailhead.
Lamoille River Walk.features: Enjoy a bounty of nature and experience a walking trail through beautiful evergreens, ferns and wildflowers along the Lamoille River.

Ottauquechee Trail.name: Ottauquechee Trail
Ottauquechee Trail.trailhead: From Quechee Main Street at Route 4, continue towards Quechee, turning left onto Deweys Pond Road. Continue 1000' to parking on left at polo field.
Ottauquechee Trail.features: This footpath follows the tree line along the edge of the Quechee Polo Field to Quechee Main Street where it crosses the street and turns west towards Marshland Farm, paralleling the road on it's way.  Cross the front of the Quechee Inn's lawn to reach a continuation of the the trail to Quechee Village.

Five Tree Hill Trail.name: Five Tree Hill Trail
Five Tree Hill Trail.trailhead: From Tafts Corners in Williston, take Route 2A south 1.5 miles. Turn left onto Old Creamery Road. After 0.75 mile, turn right onto Sunset Hill Road. Follow this road for another 0.75 mile to find a small parking area on the left. The trailhead is on the right side of the road.
Five Tree Hill Trail.features:
Named for the five large sugar maples located near the overlook, the destination of a 1.3 mile hiking trail, Five Tree Hill offers 50 acres of open space and fantastic hiking opportunities for residents.  The Five Tree Hill trail can be linked to the Mud Pond Conservation Area trail to form a 4.5 mile hiking corridor.  A map is available.  Hiking and walking only, no bicycling or motorized vehicles allowed.  Parking is available on Sunset Road.

Great views on top of Five Tree Hill. Family friendly.

Heart of the Islands Bike Tour :: 25-Mil.name: Heart of the Islands Bike Tour :: 25-Mile Route
Heart of the Islands Bike Tour :: 25-Mil.trailhead: The tour starts at Snow Farm Winery in South Hero.
Heart of the Islands Bike Tour :: 25-Mil.features: Bike to the heart of the Champlain Islands on July 9th with Vermont Farm Tours during the fourth annual Open Farm and Studio Weekend.

Bear Swamp Loop.name: Bear Swamp Loop
Bear Swamp Loop.trailhead: Route 12 north from Montpelier, left turn onto Shady Rill Road. The route begins just past Rumney School at the junction with Story Road and East Bear Swamp Road. Parking at the Hunger Mountain trailhead (approx. 10-12 cars) or on the wide shoulder adjacent to the Rumeny School athletic fields (>20 cars).
Bear Swamp Loop.features: Beaver Pond, views of Worcester Range including Mount Hunger, Mt Hunger hiking trail trailhead

Essex Bike Path.name: Essex Bike Path
Essex Bike Path.trailhead:
At the southern end, bike path begins on Route 15/Main St. at the northeast corner of the intersection of Densmore Drive and Route 15.

At the northern end, pick it up at Essex Way where it intersects Route 15/Center Rd.
Essex Bike Path.features: Walk, run, bike, rollerblade along the 2.5 mile paved bike path.

Wright Park.name: Wright Park
Wright Park.trailhead: Begin either at the Belden Dam area north of the park or at the southem entrance off of Seymour St. in Middlebury.
Wright Park.features: The trails are mostly in the woods along the Otter Creek River. Sumner Homestead 1875 historic landmark. Belden Falls and Arnold suspension Bridge

Trout Pond Forest.name: Trout Pond Forest
Trout Pond Forest.trailhead: From the Lyme Center Post Office head east toward the Skiway and turn left onto Acorn Hill Rd. Turn right onto Hardscrabble Lane after 1.7 miles. At junction with Pony Hill Lane, continue straight ahead ½ mile to the parking area, marked by a blue sign. The trail bears right just beyond the parking area. The access road is rough and may not be suitable for low profile vehicles, and is not maintained in winter; if necessary, park at the intersection of Hardscrabble and Pony Hill Lanes.
Trout Pond Forest.features: Nice hike to scenic pond surrounded by boulders with local views.  A wonderful view of Smarts Mountain.

Williston Village Bike Path.name: Williston Village Bike Path
Williston Village Bike Path.trailhead: Parking is available at Allen Brook School and the Williston Community Park, behind Williston Central School
Williston Village Bike Path.features: Connects Williston neighborhoods, schools, parks and natural areas.

Safford Uplands Nature Preserve.name: Safford Uplands Nature Preserve
Safford Uplands Nature Preserve.trailhead:
See map - there is an informational sign at the trailhead on Cochran Road
Do not park anywhere on Orchard Lane. Park at the Beeken Rivershore Preserve Canoe Launch, shown on this map.
Parking
Beeken Rivershore Preserve Canoe Launch. Please         park here and take the marked Rivershore Trail to its exit onto         Cochran Road near the entrance to the Safford Preserve. You         could also walk along Cochran Road from the Canoe Launch to the         Safford Preserve. (Note: The Rivershore Trail also continues         west from this point.) Limited parking is also available in a         space near the intersection of Wes White Hill Rd. and Cochran         Rd., immediately east of the Cochran Rd. bridge over the         Huntington River. Access to the preserve is only from Cochran         Rd.
Safford Uplands Nature Preserve.features: Peaceful hike through wooded hillside land conserved by the late George Safford and donated to the Richmond Land Trust. Occasional views of the Winooski River valley.

Roads Less Traveled.name: Roads Less Traveled
Roads Less Traveled.trailhead: Park and Ride, 1/4 mile north of intersection of Routes 2 and 7 on Colchester/Milton town line.
Roads Less Traveled.features: A back roads route around Milton and Colchester. Arrowhead Lake and the historic streets of Milton and Colchester interest the rider en route.

Allen Brook Nature Trail.name: Allen Brook Nature Trail
Allen Brook Nature Trail.trailhead:
Located off the Williston Village Bike Path (red line on map) opposite the right field foul line of the Little League field at Williston Central School.
Access the school from Williston Road (Route 2) in the town of Williston via Library Lane (exit via Central School Drive, roads are one-way).
Allen Brook Nature Trail.features:
The trail includes a half mile loop,  a wildlife observation boardwalk and an extension trail connecting to the Chatham Woods development and North Williston Rd.  Great for a family walk or ski.

Also, the Williston Community Park (Located behind Williston Central School) offers two soccer fields, two softball fields, a Little Leaque field, Babe Ruth field, two sand volleyball courts, horseshoe pits, and a skating rink.

The Village Bike Path (red line on map) runs through this park making it an excellent destination for all kinds of recreation. Also located nearby are two tennis courts and an outdoor basketball court with lights for evening play. Parking is available.

Cobb Forest Loop.name: Cobb Forest Loop
Cobb Forest Loop.features: Loop trail in the Municipal forest near the north end of Sawyer Road offers a diversity of interesting plant life and the possibility of seeing animal signs from bear and moose.

Taconic Mountains Ramble.name: Taconic Mountains Ramble
Taconic Mountains Ramble.trailhead: From VT Route 4 west of Rutland take exit 5 toward Hubbardton Battlefield. Travel about 6 miles to St. John Road on your left. If you come to the Hubbardton Battlefield, you've gone too far! The driveway to the trailhead will be on the left side about another 6 miles. Continue down the driveway past the first cattle guard into a pine forest, past the cow pasture, and over the second cattle guard. The Parking area is to the left. The Kiosk is down by the house.
Taconic Mountains Ramble.features: The trail system offers amazing rock features, wide panoramic views, and is blazed in red and yellow.

Delta Park.name: Delta Park
Delta Park.trailhead: Take Rt. 127 North to Colchester. Turn left onto Porters Point Road. Turn left onto Colchester Point Road, left again onto Windemere Way which leads to Delta Park.  From Burlington, follow Burlington's Island Line Trail north until you cross the bridge over the Winooski River.
Delta Park.features: Unique wetland river delta. Views of the River, Lake, the Adirondacks and wetlands are everywhere you look.

Central Vermont Regional Path (South Bar.name: Central Vermont Regional Path (South Barre Section)
Central Vermont Regional Path (South Bar.features: A flat paved path that extends from Fair View Street past Barre City Elementary School.

Wright's Mountain Trails.name: Wright's Mountain Trails
Wright's Mountain Trails.trailhead:
DIRECTIONS  TO  DEVIL'S  DEN  TRAILHEAD PARKING
From Bradford's only traffic light at the intersection of Routes 5 & 25, head on Route 25 West for 4 miles.  Turn right onto  Chase Hollow Road.  Travel approximately 1.2 miles,  and the parking area is on the left.
DIRECTIONS  TO  WRIGHTS  MT  TRAILHEAD  PARKING
From Bradford's only traffic light at the intersections of Routes 5 & 25, head on Route 25 West for 5.2 miles.  Turn right onto Wrights MT Road.  Go approximately 2.4 miles to the height of  the land; parking area is on the right.
Wright's Mountain Trails.features: Take a tour through the network of paths and old logging roads meandering around Wright's Mountain, Bradford's highest peak at 1,822 feet, and enjoy a wonderful view of the Waits River Valley from the summit.

Salmon Hole Park.name: Salmon Hole Park
Salmon Hole Park.trailhead: The trailhead parking lot is on Riverside Avenue in Burlington, just 200 yards before the bridge to Winooski.
Salmon Hole Park.features: River overlook, stepping stones, view of the old mills.

Nature Trail.name: Nature Trail
Nature Trail.trailhead: Trailhead / parking located north of the Charlestown Fire Station. The trail kiosk is north across a small field.
Nature Trail.features: A variety of habitats. Used by the school for nature education.

Winooski River Walk.name: Winooski River Walk
Winooski River Walk.trailhead: Off Main Street in Downtown Winooski, near the start of the Winooski/Burlington bridge. Parking and canoe launch are available behind the Millyard Condominiums on West Canal Street. Trail signage and tiny parking lot at Route 15 and railroad tracks.
Winooski River Walk.features: Up close views of the Winooski and its falls, plus historic Champlain Mill and Woolen Mill. Family friendly.

Pine Hill Park Pedestrian Trails.name: Pine Hill Park Pedestrian Trails
Pine Hill Park Pedestrian Trails.trailhead: From Route 7 turn west on Crescent Street (just north of the Route 7/Route 4 intersection).  Turn Right on to Fairview.  Turn left on to Oak Street Extension and right into Giorgetti Athletic Complex parking lot.  The trailhead is at the west end of the parking area.
Pine Hill Park Pedestrian Trails.features: The park offers a unique 300 acre, highly refined 16 mile singletrack trail system offering some of the very best: Mountain Biking, Running, Hiking, Walking, GPSing/Geocaching, Snowshoeing in the central Vermont region. (Sorry No ATV Access)

Wolfrun Natural Area and Gateway Land.name: Wolfrun Natural Area and Gateway Land
Wolfrun Natural Area and Gateway Land.trailhead:
From Route 2 in Joneville, take Stage Road (north) for 4.2 miles to the intersection with Leary Road.  Alternatively take Leary Road or Stage Road south from Nashville Road to where they join. This intersection is your landmark.  Trails are accessed from a point either 250 feet south of this intersection (driveway by empty house) or 0.6 miles south of this intersection (VAST trail in winter).
Parking - Seasonal - not plowed: At the northern Trailhead, limited partking is available by the side of the driveway across from the empty trailer.  At the southern Trailhead, there is limited parking a short distance south on the opposite side of Stage Road (the access to Preston Pond).
Wolfrun Natural Area and Gateway Land.features:
Trails are on two properties owned and managed by the Jericho Underhill Land Trust (JULT).  The Gateway land encompasses 123 acres of prime wildlife habitat, multiple potential home sites, extensive trails and provides access to the Wolfrun Natural Area. Accessed just South of Wolfrun off Stage Road in Bolton through a literal gateway at the entrance to the VAST trail.
Dogs allowed - on leash
Certain areas are closed seasonally for wildlife protection - please be alert for trail closure signs, and respect them.

Connecticut River State Forest Trail.name: Connecticut River State Forest Trail
Connecticut River State Forest Trail.trailhead: From Main St., head east onto East St., go south past the primary school and up the dirt road to the trailhead by the kiosk. The trail is further down the class 6 road.
Connecticut River State Forest Trail.features: Steep climb up an old logging road, then into the forest.

Waitsfield Village Path.name: Waitsfield Village Path
Waitsfield Village Path.trailhead: The Town Pond Access Point is located at the junction of Route 100 and Carroll Road
Waitsfield Village Path.features: The 1.75 mile path meanders south to the Mad River Green shopping center via a picturesque boardwalk and open meadow.

Little Country Hills.name: Little Country Hills
Little Country Hills.trailhead: Shelburne Village Green across from Shelburne Country Store, just off Route 7.
Little Country Hills.features: Suburban neighborhoods, country roads, and country stores, plus a stop at Shelburne Farms highlights this tour.

Phillips Trail.name: Phillips Trail
Phillips Trail.trailhead: Trailhead is at a farm road approximately 0.6 miles south on Elm Street from the intersection with US Route 7.
Phillips Trail.features: Easy hike through meadows near Pittsford.

Hawk Hill.name: Hawk Hill
Hawk Hill.trailhead: From Route 7 turn in to Otter Valley Union High School parking lot, 3.1 miles south of Brandon.  Park at south end of main school parking lot.  Large kiosk across athletic fields a quarter mile to the south marks trailhead.
Hawk Hill.features: Lovely, wooded walking trails on woods and hills behind Otter Valley Union High School.  This area is the original settlement area for Old Brandon.

Bald Mountain Trail.name: Bald Mountain Trail
Bald Mountain Trail.trailhead: From the US 7 and US 4 in Rutland follow Route 7 south to the the traffic light at Killington Avenue.  Turn east on to Killington Avenue.  Follow for 1.8 miles to its end at the junction of Town Line Road and Notch Road.  Turn right onto the paved Notch Road (0.0 miles) and continue past the end of the pavement through Tamarack Notch, and bear right at the fork (1.9 miles) where the Wheelerville Road departs to the left.  The trailhead is soon reached on the right (2.1 miles)  where Notch Road levels out just before crossing the brook. Park on shoulder. Additional parking is available just past the trailhead on the right.
Bald Mountain Trail.features: This hike offers the main loop (East Loop) which is 3.3 miles and can be lengthened by adding the West Loop (0.9miles).  Close to Rutland and therefore easy to access this is a great, local trail to enjoy with nice views from several vistas.

Hypertherm Trails.name: Hypertherm Trails
Hypertherm Trails.trailhead:
From Route 120 north towards Hanover, turn right onto Greensboro Road and continue until you reach a "T" intersection, stay right onto Great Hollow Road.
In 0.4 miles turn right into the Hypertherm driveway continuing past the main building to the uppermost parking lot.  Please do not park on the basketball court.  The trailhead begins at the top of the driveway just right of the basketball court..
Hypertherm Trails.features:
Several loop trails originally designed for Mountain Bike single track are available for walkers, runners, mtn. bikes and for snowshoeing.
Note: The trails depicted in the trail network on this Trail Finder map are not color coded by use or trail surface type. Instead, colors used divide the trail network into separate trail sections.
The primary orange loop is currently signed and easy to follow. Other loops are currently not marked and are more difficult to navigate and a GPS or compass may be needed to assist in navigation back to the trailhead.

Montpelier - Wells River Rail Trail (New.name: Montpelier - Wells River Rail Trail (Newbury)
Montpelier - Wells River Rail Trail (New.trailhead: Trailhead at Boltonville, with parking, north side of Rte 302 just east of jct Rte 302 and Boltonville Rd. (Just over half mile west of I-91 Exit 17).
Montpelier - Wells River Rail Trail (New.features: Gradual pleasant walk or easy bike among stands of large trees with views of Wells River, wetlands, farm.

Moody Park.name: Moody Park
Moody Park.trailhead:
From downtown Claremont, follow Pleasant St. (Rtes. 11/12) for 0.9 miles to Maple Avenue. Continue on Maple Avenue for 0.8 miles to reach Moody Park Road on your left.
Alternatively, from Rte. 12 east of the Connecticut River at the 12A intersection, head west for 1.0 mile to Plains Road. Turn right and continue for 1.7 miles to Maple Avenue. Turn left and continue for 0.8 miles to Moody Park Road, located on your right.
Moody Park.features: 325 Acre Park with Multi-Purpose Woodland Trails for Hiking, Cross-Country Skiing, Running, Mountain Biking, etc.

Battery Park.name: Battery Park
Battery Park.features: Burlington's most popular spot to watch the sunset. Includes walking path parallel to Battery Street and lots of local history.

Island Line Trail.name: Island Line Trail
Island Line Trail.trailhead:
Numerous access points along the Burlington and Colchester waterfronts.

Southend of Burlington: Take Shelburne Road (Route 7) south. At Flynn Avenue, turn right. Take Flynn Avenue to the end to Oakledge Park. Check in with park attendant and park.
Downtown Burlington: Take Main Street west towards the waterfront. Follow the road past Battery Street as it curves to the right. At the next intersection, turn left onto College Street. You will find a public parking lot on the right hand side.
Colchester: Take Route 127 north and turn left onto Porter's Point Road. Turn left onto Colchester Point Road. Airport Park will be on the right and has parking and trail access.
South Hero: Take Route 2 north to South Hero village. Turn left on South St. and continue 2.5 miles. Turn Right onto Martin Rd. After 1/3 mile, look for the trail on the left. Please use the parking lot off the road.
Island Line Trail.features:
Waterfront views of Lake Champlain from Burlington to Colchester. Numerous parks and natural areas along the way, a trail bridge over the mouth of the Winooski River, and Colchester's Causeway Park. Restrooms are available at Oak Ledge Park, Perkins Pier, the waterfront Boathouse, the Skate Park, North Beach, Leddy Beach, Charlie's Boathouse and Airport Park.

Please Note: Update November 2012
COLCHESTER
Thanks to all who donated to The Big Fix and the Friends of the Island Line, the Colchester Causeway reopened on October 26, 2012!
Thank you to the Town of Colchester, FEMA, SD Ireland and all the private donors who helped with the local match.
The Causeway was closed  after large sections were washed out by high winds and the record-setting water level of Lake Champlain in Spring 2011.

BURLINGTON:
Initial repair from the 2011 flood has been completed along along this 7 mile southern section. Burlington is now working on additional flood repair work on the waterfront path.  Sections will be closed for repairs.

SOUTH HERO:
Currently open for pedestrians. State hopes to start repairs in the fall of 2012. Entire trail will be closed during construction.

THE CAUSEWAY BIKE FERRY:
Bike Ferry did not run in 2012 because of causeway repair work.  Fundraising is underway to start construction for ferry service in 2013.  You can help, click on: www.localmotion.org/thebigfix

Lincoln Gap West Vista.name: Lincoln Gap West Vista
Lincoln Gap West Vista.trailhead: The trail head is in the Town of Lincoln on the Lincoln Gap Road.
Lincoln Gap West Vista.features: 10-20 minute walk for a scenic view of wilderness.
